direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The two boys tromp out of the closet. The rubber turn-out boots are as high as their thighs. The ends of the coats drag on the floor. They salute, Brian's arm just an empty sleeve. Dennis kneels down and re-fastens Brian's coat.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Your brother's right. If you don't fasten these correctly they could open and you'd get burned.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: And DIE!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You wouldn't let me die, would you, Dad?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: McCaffreys are smarter than fire, Brian. (playfully slaps their shoulders) How 'bout lunch, huh?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Fireman shit?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Hey, what's with the mouth? Where'd you grow up, a barn?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Firehouse.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Cute.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The station suddenly fills with the BELLOW of an ALARM KLAXON.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: A young fireman, ADCOX, appears with the dispatch card.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Dennis scoops Brian up and loads him into the fire engine cab. The other three firemen climb aboard and take their places.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (sighs) Never fails...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Big deal?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Medium deal.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Want to come along, Brian? Watch the old man earn his keep?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (pissed) Dad!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You've come along a dozen times, Stephen, give your brother a chance. We'll be back in a few minutes. (to Brian) How 'bout it, sport?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Sure!

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: There's a cough of diesel, a crunch of gears, and the engine is pulling out of the station.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian stamps his foot on the siren button. The red light snaps on, the siren growls and blares, and they're off down the street. Brian turns around in his seat and, at the last instant before the corner, makes eye contact with his older brother. They stick their tongues out.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Hit the button, Brian.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: DAY - 20 YRS. EARLIER The engine howls its way through the city. Brian, sandwiched between his father and Adcox, looks out in wonderment at intersections zipping past like picket fences, at people on sidewalks holding hands over their ears, at the red emergency lights bouncing crazily off shop windows.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: DAY - 20 YRS. EARLIER Lazy smoke curls out the second story of a commercial block. Medium deal. The engine pulls up and the firemen are jumping off like ship rats. Dennis opens his door, hops down, and pauses just long enough to point a serious finger at his son.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian nods vigorously, taking the command seriously. Dennis smiles and is off, dragging a hoseline with his crew toward a doorway they disappear into. Brian climbs down from the cab.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian smiles to the pumper operator. He just wants a better look. And he gets it: Smoke turned evil and dark now, taking on purpose.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Stay near the truck. (winks) And keep an eye out for us, huh? We're short handed today.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Don't stray too far, little man.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: DAY - 20 YRS. EARLIER There's a level of apartments above the storefronts. As Brian watches, a window opens and out steps his father and Adcox onto a small fire escape. Their attention's on the next window over, out of reach, wrapped in leaky smoke. Suddenly Dennis climbs up onto the fire escape railing, armed with only an axe, and JUMPS across to the next metal balcony. A ballsy, dangerous move. He kicks in the window, breaks out the frame with his axe, and dives in. A beat later he reemerges on the balcony with a terrified, smudged little girl. He hands the little girl over the railing to a fireman now coming up the more traditional way -- a ladder. Dennis's face lifts and grins at Brian; dirty, bigger than life, invincible. He winks a wink only possible between fathers and sons and he's gone again, back into the swirling darkness. As Brian stands there, full of love, full of pride, he sees a piece of awning along the roofline crack; releasing a sickly yellow tongue of flame that slinks over the roof. The flame seems to pause, to stare at Brian a beat. Shhh, don't tell anyone. Brian is transfixed, his little head staring up in astonishment. Nobody else has noticed it. Brian can see his father and Adcox through the window; probing, looking for the flame lurking just above. Brian starts to call out in a small, hesitant voice,

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: He tries to call louder... But suddenly everything is happening very fast in slow motion:

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Dad...

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian can see Adcox testing the ceiling with a pike pole as Brian steps forward, under the power of a flame that beckons him as -- Dennis suddenly THROWS his body against Adcox, knocking him clear just as a flame EXPLODES DOWNWARD from the ceiling fully against him as -- All the building's windows BLOW OUT and it's like the sky's erupted for Brian, a burning hailstorm that falls and pelts the ground around him. Plaster, wood, and something metal that cracks against the pavement and spins slowly. A fire helmet. And Adcox is coming out the door now, blackened and torn, hopeless tears streaming down his face.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: And, spotting Brian, he runs towards him. And the helmet spins and spins and Adcox keeps running, and the sky is raining fire, and the flame on the roof has risen up now to its full, horrifying size and it's laughing now, laughing at the little boy as the helmet finally stops spinning, and we read the printing on the neck guard.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Get us some backup! We need some goddamn backup!

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: And Adcox is sobbing and has his arms around the boy, protecting him from the fire, the world, but it's like Brian doesn't see him. He pulls away from Adcox, walks up to his father's helmet, And puts it on. The scene EXPLODES with a flash as a photographer captures the instant.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Hold on the freeze-frame. Let it become an aged cover of LIFE. The magazine jiggles and rocks and we see now it's sitting atop a box of knick-knacks jostling in the back seat of an aging BMW. There's plenty of other boxes here, a live on the move, and in the driver's seat, BRIAN McCAFFREY, now 27. There's piles of empty burger wrappers, Coke cans, and Florida knick-knacks on the dash board; a little blow-up palm tree, a cheesy hula girl emblazoned with "McCaffrey High-End Stereo Sales".

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian and his battered BMW shoot past prairie, cow country, nervous suburbs and finally a sign: WELCOME TO CHICAGO.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Wind tugging at his bangs, Brian stares down at the graves of Dennis and Mary Elizabeth McCaffrey.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: In a crusty sink he combs his hair, knots a tie around his neck.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian walks through its sculpted columns, straightening his tie. He comes to a door, FIRE ACADEMY CHIEF. He takes a deep breath, steadies his gaze, and enters.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The ACADEMY CHIEF sits at his desk going over a file. Out the window can be heard a FIRE TRAINING CLASS in action.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian's sitting in the seat opposite.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: As we hear the BLOW OF A WHISTLE CUT TO:

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Is this a joke?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: If it was a joke, sir, you'd be laughing.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You walked out on this academy six years ago. One week to graduation. You think we forgot that? You think I did?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I want another shot, Sir.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (beat) Look, everybody remembers your old man. Being his son, all you had to do was breathe to graduate here. Dead Hero Father Rule. But you blew us off. Why should I take you back?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: If you remember, sir, my test scores were in the top -- CHIEF FITZGERALD -- I don't give a damn what your test scores were, maybe you could have been a good firemen, but you had your shot.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I need another one, sir.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Sorry, but it's out of my hands. Try again next year.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: No, it isn't out of your hands or you wouldn't even have met me. If I push you have to let me back in. Dead Hero Father Rule. Sir.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (simmers) Even if you graduate this academy, you've still got nine months of probation. That's hard duty, son. If you don't really love this job, it'll kill you.

result.heading: BLOW OF A WHISTLE CUT TO

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (rises) See you Monday. Sir.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: . TRAINING ACADEMY - GRADUATION DAY And everybody lined up at attention in dress blues.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Candidates and their relatives CHEER and leap to their feet. Something struggles inside of Brian. He doesn't stand at first. Another Candidate, TIM, 20, looks at him strangely. So does the Academy Chief, his eyes finding Brian's. And Brian's standing slowly now, joining them...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (at podium) Though the world changes every day, some things are truly forever: Courage, devotion, and honor in what we do. This class is a special one, for we dedicate it to the three firefighters that have fallen this year: Donald Knowlton, Richard Walter and Michael Petzold... (silent beat) Ladies and gentlemen, it is with pleasure that I certify that Candidate Class number 322, having successfully completed all academy requirements, are hereby graduated to the Chicago Fire Department.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: An expensive one. We hear a window BREAK.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Through the dimness a file cabinet. An AXE SUDDENLY SLAMS into it, RIPPING it apart. Files crash to the floor. And a picture. 1970. Four young guys marlin fishing. Time of their lives.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: And a GREY PUTTY being SLAPPED along the edges of a door.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: A split-level firemen's dive; complete with mounted axes and personalized T-shirts from various engine companies proudly declaring "LADDER CO. 6 -- AXE FIRST, HOSE LATER" and "CHICAGO FD, 150 YEARS OF TRADITION UNIMPEDED BY PROGRESS". Tonight the place is firmly in the hands of an army of recently graduated candidates. A few on the back patio have hooked up a charged hoseline and are taking potshots at balloon targets, each other, the neighbor's cat. Brian and Tim, still in their uniforms, enter from the street. Survey the scene.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: As they shoulder their way inside, another CANDIDATE appears holding proudly a fistful of sealed envelopes.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Tim and everyone else but Brian eagerly tear into them. Brian nonchalantly shoulders up to the bar.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The barkeep turns and smiles.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The candidates are ripping open their assignments, exclaiming to each other: "All right! Engine 117! That's a slum! They get cookers every day!". "Oh no, Engine 10, that's a nice neighborhood"... Willy turns to the bulletin board behind him and unpins a stack of business cards.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Tim holds an envelope marked McCAFFREY out to Brian.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: On Brian's reaction

result.heading: "CHICAGO FD, 150 YEARS OF TRADITION UNIMPEDED BY PROGRESS"

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Completely out of control.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: What the hell are we waiting for?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Hot off the presses, guys. Station assignments.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: A beer, Willy!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Well, if it isn't the littlest McCaffrey. (to candidates with hose) Hey! You break anything with that you buy it! (to Brian) Sorry, there must be something wrong with my eyes. I keep thinking that's a fire department uniform.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: It's in my blood, Willy.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Really. Well, let's have a look at what else was "in your blood". I always look forward to getting these, they make such a nice collage for the bar... "Assistant Director, Sales, Aspen Snowmobile Tours..."

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Didn't offer the kinda growth and challenge I need.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Uh huh. And "Pioneer's Pride, Mobile Log Cabins". That was in your blood about six months wasn't it?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Management were pin heads.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: "Laguna Jamming, Custom Surfboards"?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Coffee sucked.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: And just this year, "Brian's Sound Spectrum". Your own company even. Big step.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I was ahead of my time.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You know, I've got a perfect little spot here for "Brian McCaffrey, Fireman"...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Aren't you even curious?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Engine 115, right?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (opens it, surprised) How'd you know? These are supposed to be sealed.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Lucky guess. (winks) And a case of scotch to a captain in station assignments.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You crooked son of a bitch. Why 115?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Lots of fires. They promote faster there. Take a look at the last Lt.'s list, half the guys on it came from that battalion. Gotta think about your future, Timmy. 115's the station.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Ah man, if you're gonna bribe your way into a station, why not 17 with me and your brother?

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Porsche knifes through darkened streets. The DRIVER, 50, is dressed for success. Pulling up to the brownstone we saw earlier, he gets out and rubs his eyes. Another day in the salt mines. Climbing the short stairs, he sticks his key into the lock and opens the door. It is the last thing he will ever do.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: the stoop.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The place is packed now with girls flirting with the candidates, putting their helmets on, etc. The horseplay around the bar suddenly stops at the sweet sound of a SIREN.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Everyone steps outside, cocks an ear. And here it comes, the real thing, SCREECHING past in a full-tilt rush. Shouts and raised toasts.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: As Brian turns, he suddenly confronted by an elderly LITHUANIAN WOMAN.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: She grabs his cheeks and rattles off in Lithuanian. Brian can only smile. Then two attractive jean-clad legs step up. JENNIFER.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Just then, Tim OPENS UP the hoseline, DRENCHING Brian.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian ducks the stream and PULLS a length of hose near his feet, FLIPPING Tim. Brian JUMPS him, shuts off the hose and pins him to the pavement.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian walks back toward Jennifer

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: She turns to leave.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Another in a series of fire engines HOWL past. Tim grabs Brian by the shoulder.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Hey, that's my cousin's company! C'mon! Let's go!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (surprised) Mrs. Viatkus...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Brian.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (surprised) Jennifer.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You're back.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You look great.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Thanks for calling.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Uh... I've been sorta keeping a low profile... the academy... I graduated today.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Huh.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: So... I see you're still in the neighborhood.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Not quite. Just visiting. I live in Lincoln Park now.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Yeah? What have you been up to?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I work for city hall.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Really? No kidding.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: What, you think I just dried up and blew away when you left? The world does turn once in awhile Brian, even without your permission.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Don't want you overheating, Brian!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Okay okay! Uncle!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You've certainly matured.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Well, if nothing else, it's nice to know we can still be friends.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I don't want to be your friend, Brian.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Let's go, man!

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian and Tim jump into Brian's car. They shoot blindly down the street looking for the fire engine, running down red lights or anything else that gets in their way. Brian suddenly hits the brakes, SCREECHING to a stop. They roll down their windows. Far off can be heard the wind-up of a siren.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (points) That way.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: . They fly around a corner, down a block, and there it is, lights flashing up ahead. Brian GUNS it, roars up alongside the fire engine. Tim leans out the window, shakes a bottle of beer, and lets loose a foamy eruption in the truck driver's face.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: But he's laughing.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Tim! You crazy motherfucker!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: What'cha got?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Box alarm. Walton Ave.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: We'll meet ya.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: As Brian and Tim pull up two engine companies are already dragging lines toward the rolling brownstone we saw explode earlier. Tim cheers the firemen on like a drive-in movie. Brian watches the fire with uneasy fascination. Embers whipping into the night, drifting to the ground around him. One of the engine companies is entering the doorway now. He watches as they willingly crawl into a place any sane person would run for their life from. Jesus Christ. FLASH -- Brian turns at the blinding snap of a camera. Several locals are gathered around a parked car, some taking pictures. Brian notices that right away. It takes a beat longer to notice the CHARRED CORPSE stuffed head-first through the windshield. It's the Porsche driver, his legs sticking out at crazy angles. A dog barks furiously at it.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The brownstone fire quickly transforms itself into noisy clouds of dirty white steam. And one of the firemen is coming back out now, walking toward Brian. When he's just a few yards away he pulls off his air mask and helmet and we shudder with Brian, because the man is a dead ringer for HIS FATHER.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: He pats Brian's cheeks, leaving behind large charcoal smears.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: And Stephen turns for his own men, Tim staring at Brian as clouds of smoke drift past like ghosts.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (also looking at body) Man. Something sure put a crimp in his evening.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Backdraft.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Well, look what we have here. Nice costume. Rent it?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I want to thank you for coming to my graduation, Stephen. It was a great inspiration to me.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: So you're going to fight fires now, huh?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (re smears) Doesn't work on you. (turns to leave) See ya around, little brother.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Not likely.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (turns) Well, see you're wrong already. Had a talk with Chief Fitzgerald, and we decided in the interest of brotherly love, that maybe you shouldn't be way over on the other side of town. So starting tomorrow, your assigned to company 17. My company. (Brian's color drops a hue) One case of scotch, you're getting cheap in your old age, Brian...

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: A flame LEAPS up into the foreground. Touches a cigarette. The cigarette glows, lingers, then lowers slowly from the mouth of RIMGALE, fifty-five years old and six and a half feet of solid granite. Wearing a windbreaker and grey slacks tucked into fire department rubber boots, he takes another slow drag. Looks at the body stuffed into the windshield. It's twenty yards away from the brownstone. Stephen looks up as Rimgale drops the cigarette, crushes it with his boot, and crosses the street to the building.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Charred walls hiss and snap in the steamy darkness. Rimgale is there, gloomy in the beam of his flashlight. He crouches down, plays his flashlight along the ruined baseboard.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen is leaning in the doorway, watching him.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale's flashlight finds a wall socket that he pries loose and holds up to the light. He lowers it, takes in the walls, the room.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: If you stare any longer Stevie, I'll start charging you admission.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Got a cause?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Are the glory boys actually showing interest in Investigation's work? I may have a stroke.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: The glory boys just want to finish their report so they can go home.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: They're gonna have to wait a few days on this one.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Tim's talking to his cousin. Brian hangs back, watches the body-bag people load the Porsche driver into a meat wagon. There's a still an audience for this, still stray dogs circling and barking. Brian walks up, looks inside the car, and sees on a seat the ragged remains of a FINGER.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: They're already climbing into the wagon. The driver smiles creepily.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian looks across the fireground, sees his brother walking back to the fire engine. They share a brief, edgy glance.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (to coroner crew) Hey, you forgot... this.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: We always leave something for the dogs.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: A modest one. South-side Irish old fashioned. Brian walks up. There's a little kid, about five, playing with a toy fire truck on the drive.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The kid stares at him without a glimmer of recognition.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: He makes his hand into a talking puppet.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The kid drops his toy truck and flees inside.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Sean. What's goin' on, man?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: It's Uncle Brian. Y'know.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (bandito accent) "Spinach? We don't need no stinking spinach". Remember?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Mom! Mom!

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian follows, sticks his head in the door.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: A warm looking woman, 30's, HELEN, comes around the corner.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: She gives him a tentative hug.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Helen's expression suddenly saddens.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The little kid is peeking fearfully from the kitchen doorway.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: And the kid runs unexpectedly away, angry.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: An embarrassed sting.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Hellooo...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Brian?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Hi, Helen. Man, you look great.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You look like... Brian.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: 'Bout written you off. How long have you been in town?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Four months.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Four months?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I know, I know, Should'a called. I've been really busy. I joined the fire department.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Oh Brian... (beat) You guys... you really know how to put each other through it, don't you?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: That's Sean? Jeez, he's a giant.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, you'd be surprised what three years can do to a kid.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Sean, come on out, man. What, you forget your favorite uncle?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Stephen told him you were killed in a hot tub accident.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (intense) Dad was kidding, Mom.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Well that's two things to strangle Stephen for. Where is he, anyway?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (beat) Stephen's not staying here now, Brian. He moved out last April.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Oh, man, I'm sorry.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You guys ought to try picking up a phone once in awhile.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: A small one on the river. Several boats bob peacefully. Except one. Raised high in dry-dock, it's an ancient fishing trawler. Bachman-Turner-Overdrive drifts up from the galley on badly fuzzed speakers as Brian climbs the ladder.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stripped to the waist, Stephen's bent-over cleaning out the guts of the inboard motor. He looks confused to see Brian.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Wrong thing to say. Stephen turns back to his work.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen straightens up, his forearms smudged with grease. Brian admires the unwashed cereal bowls and peeling deck paint.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen tosses him a beer from the fridge. As Brian pops it, he sees the small pile of city-issue gallon size cans in the corner. Armorall, solvent, extinguisher foam.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian winces at the music coming out of shot speakers.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian lifts one of the tapes -- an 8-track -- and holds it carefully in his palm as if it were a rare and fragile relic.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Hey.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I talked to Helen...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: ...Man, I thought dad's boat was finally retired to the family graveyard. Don't you worry about falling out of this thing?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I like what you've done with the place.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: It's comin' along... want a beer?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Been ripping off fire stations?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: It's old stuff Adcox gave me that the department was going to throw out anyway. Still good enough though for this tub.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Bachman Turner Overdrive? (looks through music rack) ...Buffalo Springfield?... Stephen Bishop? Oh man...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: My God, an actual operating 8-track.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: What, you've never seen one before?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: In the Field Museum once.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: It works.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: It worked when you were in sixth grade.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian opens the trunk of his old BMW. It's full of stereo boxes marked BRIAN'S "SOUND SPECTRUM".

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian's gutted the speakers and is re-wiring them.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian moves over to another speaker.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian staples the last of the audio cord in place and switches on the tape player. The cabin fills with sharp, crystal clear -- Stephen Bishop.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: People actually used to pay you for this?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Millions, Stephen -- And sexual favors.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Sheep don't count.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Yeah? What about Laura -- STEPHEN That was never proved.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Why'd you come here, Brian?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I wanted to know why you messed with my station assignment. I mean, is this really gonna have to one of those big brother -- little brother "you broke my GI Joe and I'm still pissed" games?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (sighs) What is it with you, man, huh? How do you manage to keep coming up with new and amazing ways to screw up? That scotch bullshit? Am I really supposed to believe you came crawling back home because you suddenly felt heart strings moan for the family biz? You were bankrupt, man.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Hey! You don't know me -- STEPHEN I know you cold, Brian. The scary thing is, you probably could have faked it for awhile. But you see, in this job there's no place to hide. Isn't like selling log cabins. You have a bad day here -- someone dies. And that's not fucking good enough. Want another beer?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: So that's it? Big bad brother's gonna ride my ass till I cough blood?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Big bad brother is going to treat you like any other probie -- that I don't think is going to make it.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: There's only so much technology can do. (picks up his tool box) Thanks for the beer.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Thanks for the speakers.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian climbs down off the boat. Looks up at Stephen.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Y'know, I told myself a million times I didn't want to be a fireman. I said bullshit to that line about tradition and family legacy. I know I split, and I know how you felt...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, you know. You know what it felt like.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I gotta do this, Stephen. I gotta know.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I think you're gonna find out, Brian. Don't be late tomorrow.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: A simple one-room walk-up. A stereo blares Chicago blues as Brian buttons up his uniform in the mirror. He steps back, looks at himself, -- and oh man what the hell am I doing...

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian climbs into his car, turns the key -- nothing. He gets out, looks under the hood, then SLAMS it down in frustration.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: A pissed-off Chicago, hauling itself off to work in the morning snap, passes by Brian's window. Tough Midwestern brick. Tough Midwesterners. Heads-down in their 150 year war with a wind committed to pushing the whole damn thing into Lake Michigan.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The train clacking away above him, Brian walks down the sidewalk carrying his fire equipment. He turns a corner and comes on.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian stands there. It's his dad's station. Turn of the century abused. Sooty with stone gargoyles and a pair of faded red doors that suddenly CRANK OPEN as Brian comes up the drive. Fire engine 17 and ladder truck 46, lights flashing, pull out onto the apron. The fireman sticking his head out of the passenger window is Stephen. One look at the silver trumpet on his collar and we know this isn't Fireman McCaffrey but Fire LT. McCaffrey.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Tim, in ladder truck 46, waves a small bye-bye as both rigs begin heading down the street.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian bolts full-out for the engine. At the last instant before he falls on his face a fireman reaches out and drags him aboard.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You're too late, probie.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (chasing) Goddamn it, Stephen...

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: It's Adcox, the fireman from the first scene, now a veteran.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The Pumper driver, SCHMIDT, pops in a howling ROCK TUNE as they zoom off.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian shouts over the noise to GRINDLE, 35, one more seat down.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Grindle sticks his nose out the window, sniffs, then begins buckling up his coat.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: As Brian and Adcox fasten up their own equipment -- EXT. FACTORY - DAY Smoke pours with confused indecision from every window of a five story factory as the pumper and ladder company pull up.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Everyone begins strapping on air tanks and masks. Adcox drags the rig's suction line to the hydrant. A beautiful illegally parked Mercedes is blocking the way.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Whistling to himself, Adcox SMASHES the brass coupling through the passenger window, runs the line through and SMASHES it out the other window before connecting up to the hydrant. Stephen and Grindle pull hose off the bed and move out. Brian's so jacked up he can't get his air tank on right. Schmidt calmly helps him into his gear.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen, Adcox and Grindle are crouched at the door, ready to go. Brian takes a hose roll and runs to catch up when he's cut-off by dazed Latin workers shouting incoherently at him in SPANISH.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian pushes past the workers and takes his position on the hose line. Stephen reaches over and re-adjusts Brian's air tank strap.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen eases the door open. Thick smoke rolls sickly out over their heads.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: And in they go...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Why baby McCaffrey, how ya doin'?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (re Brian to Adcox) You know this rug rat?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Know him? I practically raised him. (Jewish mom) And he never calls, he never writes...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I'm Brian.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Boys, I do believe we have a barbecue...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (staring at confusing smoke) I hate it when we gotta fucking go look for it.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (to Schmidt) Call in another alarm. We're gonna need some back-up.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (to Stephen) Oh these moments do try me...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (admiring car) Be gentle.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: It's only rock 'n roll, kid.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Hey, probie! How 'bout it, huh?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You're doing it wrong.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (to Brian) Stay beside me.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Inside the smoke is like liquid lead. Going by feel, they hump the hose up one staircase after another, crawling on their hands and knees toward a dull red glow. Turning a corner, they enter

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Totally ablaze. Brian looks up in wonder at the buffeting waves of flame in the ceiling, at the SCREECHING timbers crumbling to the white-hot floor. At the walls HOWLING in bestial agony. It is the most horrifying, and wonderful thing he has ever seen.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Adcox and Grindle shrug and pull their helmets down tight, expecting the worst. Adcox opens up the nozzle, turning loose a high pressure BLAST OF WATER into the ceiling. The fire SCREAMS in manic anger and HEAVES a cloud of HOWLING steam that WHIRLS back and BAKES them like lobsters. Brian gasps for air as swirling ash batters his facemask. A window somewhere EXPLODES. Somebody shouts. Christ, you can't see anything. Stephen HOOPS in victory.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The chase is on! Going for the throat while the fire's confused and defensive, the firemen SCRAMBLE through the boiling cloud. They hit it in the ceiling, in the walls, forcing it back and back. It HOWLS and CLAWS in anger, furiously throwing cinders and broken timbers in their faces. The walls ECHO with its SCREAMS as it retreats to a corner.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian runs back to the wall to hook up his hose roll to the building water system. He goes to unscrew the cap with his hydrant wrench but it keeps slipping off the nut.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian finally gets it hooked up and runs back.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Wash it to the windows?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: No, we'll hit the son of a bitch head on.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: It's gonna flash, Stevie. We gotta get behind it.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Nah, listen to it. It's a pussy. It'll just steam on us. It won't flash. Go high in the ceiling.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (to fire) I knew you were a pussy! C'mon! Steam us! (to firemen) Let's go!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Ya love it, probie?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I'm in heaven, Lt.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Hook us up to a stand-pipe.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Jesus, how 'bout man, huh? We're gonna loose this!

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Tim and three guys from his ladder company, come up an extended aerial ladder, CRASH through a window and

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: begin HACKING their way toward Brian's company as -- BOOM! It's a sudden, shattering vibration that shakes the building to its foundations. Then, a sucking sound: RUSH-RUSH-RUSH... Stephen speaks calmly into his radio handset.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The firemen hesitate. PENGELLY, the Truck Company Lt., looks at Stephen with concern.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The crews immediately gather in the center of the floor. They turn over tables, chairs, anything to form a barrier. A circling of the wagons. -- BOOM! rush-rush-rush -- BOOM! Each louder than the last. Stephen and Brian are ducked behind an overturned desk. Adcox and Krizminski clutch hoselines like frontiersmen's Winchesters.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Hey Otis, is it...?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (into radio) Yeah.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Goddamn it, where's our backup? Where's the second-in companies?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Sorry, man. John Wayne time.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (to firemen) Dig in!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Dig in, goddamn it!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You're gonna love this.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: rush-rush-rush -- CRAAAASH!! On an instant the world comes apart as all four walls of factory windows EXPLODE in a hail of glass. A wave of HOWLING FLAME POURS IN after it, SHRIEKING and HISSING. At the same moment, part of the floor beside a heavy sewing machine GIVES WAY and a ladderman, SANTOS, FALLS THROUGH, grabbing the edges at the last minute as flames BELLOW UP from underneath. He SCREAMS as his grip loosens. Grindle leaps to the ladderman's side, grabbing his arms and coat. Brian hesitates just an instant and Stephen SHOVES him out of the way to back up Grindle.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Adcox's taken the hoseline and is opening fire. Water and flame crash and snarl across the floor in a blood curdling ROAR. It's a thrashing, murderous standoff. Stephen and Grindle have got Santos but the angle's bad. Blow it now and all three could take a header. Santos is panicking, losing his grip. Grindle bores his eyes into the man's with the calm and conviction of Moses.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: They may all die, but they won't leave him. He calms a little, hangs on till they PULL him out of harm's way. Adcox continues with the hose as suddenly, everyone HITS the deck as the fire EXPLODES over them, BURSTING their coats into flame. Tim's company opens up their line, WASHING everybody down before CHARGING after the fire. A ladderman, NIGHTENGALE, steps on Brian's back.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian, stunned, sits up, his coat and helmet smoking. Stephen seems totally unaffected and is already on his feet and over the top of the barricade, the others backing him as he mercilessly drives the fire back, trapping it finally into a corner. The fire hisses, spits, shakes the walls with its furious anger. But it's all bluster now, the fire's dying.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Adcox leads Tim downstairs. Brian looks shaken up. Stephen helps him roughly to his feet.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian burns at that and shakes his brother's arm off.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian's walking over to clear the hoseline when he hears it. small voice. Faint. "Help me..."

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Nobody hears. -- Brian takes off down the other steps on his own.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Help... Oh God...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You go, we go.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Hey!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Sorry man, I thought you were dead.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (ladder co. captain) Stephen! BC's on the radio. Says they think a civilian got left behind downstairs.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Adcox! Take Tim and do a search.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Don't you fold on me now, man.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Clear the hose for me.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Hey, I think it's coming from a different staircase.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: It's only the fire's ghost here, lazy and slow. Off the corridor are rooms full of commercial sewing machines. Brian enters one and drops to his knees. Looks under a table, flashes his light behind a work stand. Nothing. He turns to backtrack his way out when A TONGUE OF FLAME suddenly LEAPS up through the floor in front of him, cutting off the door. Brian lands on his ass as it hisses and giggles and dances unreally in front of him. I never forget a face, kid. -- That fire from childhood. He could maybe force his way through but Jesus, the way it looks at him -- -- Brian ROLLS away from it. Looks for another doorway -- And ends up in thick smoke. He drops to a crawl, stays on his belly where the air's clear. When he sees it. Behind some furniture. Something flesh-colored. Shit. It's a body. He crawls up closer. It's a woman. Adrenalin pounding the top of his skull off, he grabs her and stumbles back down the hall, makes a turn -- BRIAN I got one!

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: And now he's bursting from the building onto a short fire escape, shouting at the top of his lungs.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: A sea of media flashbulbs ERUPTS in his face. The press have arrived in force, crowding the street. Brian pushes through them to a clear spot on the far side of the engine. Two fire paramedics rush over as he lowers the figure.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The paramedics suddenly stop their efforts. Turn to Brian.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: They step aside. Brian looks down. The woman looks strange. Mostly because she's a heavy store DRESSING DUMMY. The paramedics burst into laughter. Brian, looking pale and shaken, turns and walks away. He passes Grindle and Tim, sitting on the pumper's tailboard helping the REAL woman that was found inside.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Photographers have appeared and are flashing the woman. Dizzy, Brian wanders off, tries to help out with the choking clog of singed factory employees before finally turning quickly into

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I got somebody! I got somebody!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Is she... Is she alive?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I'm afraid you're a little too late with this one.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Sorry to hear about the mannequin. I heard you two were close.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Where he barfs his guts out in private. Doubled-over, one arm on the brick wall for support, we see the raw terror. The demons rushing out of him.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Someone else does too. Jennifer. Dressed now in a long expensive coat, she's standing at the end of the alley with a clipboard. Brian, ashes smeared across an ashen face, spittle on his chin, doesn't notice her.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen isn't pale. He's flushed and buoyant. All this hasn't taken anything from him. It's made his day.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen leans against the wall. Folds his arms.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen turns to leave. Brian yells after him.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen turns to walk away. Pauses.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: As Stephen leaves, we see that Jennifer's been standing at the end of the alley, listening to them. She's turns and walks as Brian looks up. We register his surprise. He watches her head toward a dynamic-looking guy in his 40s, ALDERMAN SWAYZAK, surrounded by reporters.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Shit...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (appearing beside him) You all right?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. Fine. I'm a little busy right now.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Y'know, you got an awful short memory for direct orders. I told you to stay beside me.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: C'mon, Stephen.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You split the team, man. And what was that crap with the standpipe? You'd think you and a hose were never introduced before.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Goddamn it Stephen!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I told you to stay next to me!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I was doin' it! I was up there fucking doin' it. You don't know, man, you don't know what I did!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: What you did was drop the ball, Probie. Get that right.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (from end of alley) Hey! Stevie! They're callin' for ya.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Bet 30,000 dollars a year and twenty two days a month off sounded pretty good twelve weeks ago, huh?

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: (to reporters) Roger, Paul... How's it going, guys?

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: She hands Swayzak a clipboard.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Another fire in this district. Getting to be Cinder Alley up here.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (walking up) You used that last week.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (yelling down from window) (to Brian) Hey! Probie! We're still workin' here, man.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian and the rest of the company rip open the walls and beat the last weak flames in a final flurry of dingy sparks. The moment the smoke clears just a fraction, cigarettes appear in everyone's mouth. Was it good for you? The talk is easy and obscene, the intense camaraderie of shared danger. Ash clods are thrown playfully back and forth in the afterglow of having taken on the worst there is and walking away one more time.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Adcox sees Brian. Smiles.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian turns and sees out the window Jennifer and Swayzak standing near Rimgale's red fire dept. sedan.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (to Adcox) Stephen man, what's going through that guy's head? Takin' it on in the first room... this shit's happening too often. It could've flashed. Should've flashed.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: But it didn't. Guy knows.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Guy's lucky.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Hey, baby McCaffrey. First one's the clincher. You did okay.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: My Lt. might have something to say about that.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Ah, everybody screws up some, Brian. You're working for the toughest Lt. on the job. Saw him once pick up a probie he thought was moving too slow and throw him into a burning building. It's just bad luck you're family.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (beat) John, when you're in there... in the fire... do you ever see...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (from across room, interrupting) C'mon ladies, let's roll some hose...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (to Adcox)

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Never mind.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale walks up to his sedan.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Swayzak's leaning on it. We sense the dislike between them. Swayzak steps aside. Rimgale pops the trunk.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale cuts him off with the shutting of his trunk lid.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: And he walks back to the burned building.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen's leaning out of an upstairs window. As the TV cameras turn, he drops down onto a fire engine hose bed and pops right into Swayzak's face with a murderous grin.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Grindle and Santos start walking for Stephen. Brian's there, following after them.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen silences Grindle with an outstretched hand. Swayzak leans close, out of earshot of the cameras.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Swayzak holds his ground. It's a tense, out of control moment between them. Rimgale turns from his work, watches Stephen with concern. Adcox suddenly inserts himself face-to-face with Swayzak and we see the raw hatred.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Swayzak holds Adcox's gaze, then turns for his car. Brian watches Jennifer climb in beside her boss.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Jennifer shrugs as they pull away.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Alderman Swayzak.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Investigator Rimgale.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I need to get in the trunk.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Awful expensive shoes to be wearing at a fireground, Alderman. But then I guess you haven't been to too many fires.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I wanted to talk to you about Alan Seagrave's death. We still haven't gotten a fire report from your office.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You'll have an answer as soon as I do.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: People are asking how a prominent taxpayer got stuffed through the windshield of his own car. They're asking me.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: --The point is, Investigator, you haven't even told us yet if the fire was accidental. We're starting to get the feeling your office is dragging out this case to embarrass the Alderman because of his fire dept. reorganization program -- SHADOW -- You mean his firehouse closing program, -- Don't you?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: We'd just be very disappointed if it turned out your office was playing politics.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Because I'm not. I care about this city, and I care about this department --

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (calm of a monk) Alderman, I have a remarkably uncomplicated job. To decide if a fire's arson, and if so catch the pain in the ass doing it. But to be honest, if my methodical investigative methods just happen to muck up the campaign of certain mayor wanna-bees, well, I guess I can't say I sleep any less peacefully.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I wish I could just fire the son of a bitch.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Hey! Swayzak!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: We almost lost a whole company up there, Swayzee buddy. Isn't any back- up since you closed '33. And we really appreciate it, the guys and me. Honest. I know you've got my vote for mayor.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Look Lt., I'm on your side. If there's a problem, please, work with our task force to fix it.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Oh yeah, your famous task force... three guys have already died this year because of the cuts made by your "task force"...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Stevie, c'mon man...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You see that funny glow that's starting to blink in the corner of your eye, Lt? That's your career dissipation light -- and it just went into overtime.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: If anybody's light's gonna blink, it's yours.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You're in firemanland now, Swayzak. Do yourself a favor and just walk away.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: This is your city job?

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian jumps down from the rig as it backs up the driveway. Across the street a middle-aged woman flashes them from the balcony of her apartment.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Adcox watches Brian and Tim exchange looks. Tim shrugs. Brian sighs and pulls out the pike poles, starts across the floor before freezing suddenly at a murderous GROWL. Brian turns and sees a DOG. Sort of. It has the rib cage of a wild beast, fangs, long greasy hair. It blocks his way, SNARLING with hate.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Slobber drools out of its mouth as it GROWLS.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian wipes some of the crusted grime from his face, looks back and forth between Franny and The Thing, and sighs.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: That's Franny. She likes firemen.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Tim, fill out the alarm card. (to Brian) Clean the pipe poles, wipe down the ladders and hang some hose.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: That's The Thing. You can't stay unless he likes you.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Have you guys got something against dalmatians?

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian enters, strips down his battered uniform, and opens his locker. The mannequin from the fire SPRINGS OUT, legs spread. A sign taped to its mouth says: "TAKE ME BRIAN, YOU'RE MY SUPERMAN!"

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian and the others scrub the morning's fire off their bodies in the station shower. Tim keeps filling his mouth full of water and launching it upward in a stream.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian compares himself to the praise heaped on Stephen.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian shuts off his shower and walks out.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Do you have to do that?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (pumped) Could you believe that fire? Man! First day! There I was, Adcox and me, pullin' that lady right out of the fire's fuckin' throat! I love it here -- No surround and drown for this company. Fighting 17th! Goddamn Stephen's amazing. You see how he took that fire by the balls? I'm gonna be that good some day, you watch.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Y'know what Stephen said to me, right when all the shit was coming hard? "You never know till the moment the fire stares you down if you're just gonna do this job or be great at it".

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Ah man, is he usin' that line now on you? What, you think he made that little gem up? Jesus Christ, I used to have to listen to my old man use that every morning.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen sits alone at his bunk, slowly stretching a strained and ruined back. He blows out a long, tired breath, and begins working ointment into an anciently scarred and battered knee. On the wall is a small glass case full of station memorabilia through the years. There's a two battered fire helmets there, set reverently on velvet. Beside it is a photograph of his father. Grinning. Top of the world. He's wearing a T-shirt proudly stenciled FIGHTING 17th. Father and son exchange a long, awkward greeting. In the doorway, Brian stands watching his brother, who not even 40, suddenly seems an old and broken man. The ALARM KLAXON suddenly sounds. Brian, just in a towel and Tim, in boxers covered with little dinosaurs, dash for the fire pole.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Tim and Brian slide down and bounce off the floor.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian and Tim rush for their equipment. Grindle grabs their arms.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: He hustles them across the apparatus floor, through a doorway, and into the kitchen.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: C'mon! C'mon! Go! Go!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: No! C'mon! This way!

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The makings of a meal are laid out on the counter. Brian and Tim come to a screeching halt. The rest of the station is sitting calmly at the kitchen table, watching.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: What's going on?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Dinner, Probies. Get started.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Tim and Brian, still in their boxers, set down plates of food.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Everybody digs in. The table is a craze of half a dozen different conversations. On the TV mounted above on the wall are news shots of Seagrave's body sticking out of the windshield. Adcox stands and tinks his glass with a spoon for silence.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Adcox puts his arm affectionately around the mannequin, seated with honor at the head of the table. Right beside The Thing.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The klaxon suddenly rings. Two bells. The ladder guys groan and get up.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Better be good.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Or we feed you to The Thing.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Gentlemen, please... As 17's official toastmaster -- SANTOS And bullshitter.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, Santos. Did I happen to mention that you were cut out of my will? (company laughs) I think it appropriate that we recognize the two asswipes -- I mean probationary firemen -- among us who today were baptized officially into the world of Old Man Fire. First to Tim, who despite being handicapped at birth with a rather dull expression and a really hideous pair of ears, not only took on the beast but pulled from its clutches -- assisted by a more famous and brilliant firefighter -- me -- a kicking and screaming civilian that will probably end up suing us for breaking her fingernail. (laughs) And to Brian, who's own contribution was both more beautiful and less likely to sue.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Y'know, when I heard that both McCaffrey brothers were going to be assigned together here, well, my heart was filled with... a sudden desire to transfer. (laughs) So raise a glass, lads. To funny- looking Tim, and the McCaffrey brothers, who despite years of getting on each other's nerves have managed with great effort... to still be pissed off at each other. Gentlemen!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (together, a toast) Fuck you!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Bye, boys.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (winks) We'll keep it warm for you.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Dawn lightens the room as Brian slowly opens his eyes and sees in extreme, fish-eyes close-up: THE THING GROWLING at him. Brian turns the other direction and sees Stephen, fully dressed, standing over his bunk.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Clean the toilets.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Bleary-eyed, the nine firemen line up raggedly in front of their rigs, dressed like shit but for peaked uniform caps they wear only at this moment. Stephen stands before them, does a quick glance up and down the line.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: They shuffle for the door. As Brian passes,

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Okay, company dismissed. -- See ya guys tonight at Fitzgerald's retirement party.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You want a ride?

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen pulls up. Brian opens the door.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Thanks.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Brian -- (a beat that hangs there)

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: See ya tonight.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: That's been cleared out for a huge PARTY in full swing. An Irish folk band cuts loose a merciless bagpipe beat. City brass--including Alderman Swayzak -- a few reporters, firemen and their families all mix together for this is a RETIREMENT PARTY for the Captain Fitzgerald. Brian enters, seeks out a beer at the bar. Stephen's there, swaying with what is clearly not his first drink of the evening.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Hey.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Hey.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: as a one joke gift after another is laid on the Chief. Stephen sees his ex-wife, Helen, dancing with another man. He turns away.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Santos and Grindle walk up.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen just shrugs. Brian sees Jennifer across the room. She looks great. Refined as she expertly works the room, schmoozing and hugging and calling various politicos by their first name. As she speaks to one, a waiter offers a drink. As she accepts, a bottle appears over her shoulder and splashes it with red syrup.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Her attention broken, the politico has slipped away. Annoyed, Jennifer leads Brian aside and speaks low, but angrily at him.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Jennifer instantly cuts off as a well-dressed COUPLE passes and switches stunningly into schmmoze-mode.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: They move away. Jennifer turns to Brian and switches just as fast back to their argument.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian can't help it. He cracks up.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian turns and walks away.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I gotta change the view...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Heard you didn't make the list for captain, man. I'm sorry...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (holding bottle, interrupting) With grenadine, right?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: When I was twenty.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Oooh, very sophisticated. Having fun?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Look, I'm not the same girl who had nothing better to do than wrap her legs around you on a Saturday night. This isn't about fun. I'm working here.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Carrying Swayzak's notebook?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Let me tell you something. Martin Swayzak is going to be this town's next mayor.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. Swayzak. Humanity's last hope. How can you work for that guy?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Why do you think Marty came here tonight? Because he cares about your department. You don't know how hard he works. You don't know about his programs helping West Side -- BRIAN -- All I know is that his programs are getting firemen hurt.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Bullshit. Marty's plan is only about efficiency. I've got two cousins on the job, you think I'd work for him if I didn't believe in it?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (to man)

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Tom, how nice to see you. I know Marty'll be very happy you came. Thanks so much for the donation. (to woman) Marie... how's little Kevin? Really? Seen the polls? This is the year...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: The thing that really makes me angry is the way your union has --

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: What was that? Oh man, you have picked up a few moves since John Paul II Boulevard.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, well I like to think I'm just a little past hanging out on JP II watching the Irish pick fights and Litwalks barf in the planters.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I seem to remember some pretty good nights on JP II.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Adcox is talking with another knot of firemen. He's brought a date, SALLY, a hot little number that has a habit of standing on her tip-toes when she talks.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: There's a commotion at the other end of the bar. A group of firemen have gathered around a weekly magazine.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: As they hold it up to Stephen we see a photo spread titled DARING FIRE RESCUE. The first photo shows Brian rushing out of the burning building with seemingly a woman in his arms. The second photo shows the backs of Adcox and Tim's helmets as they administered aid to the real woman they saved. The implication is it's the same woman.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The old photo is there too. Brian and his dad's helmet.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen glances over the headlines.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The other firemen jump in with drink orders. Dozens of them.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Tim shows him the magazine. Brian reads with horror as Alderman Swayzak appears beside him.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian looks at Jennifer, then smiles at Swayzak.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (looking at Swayzak across room) Yuck, what a scumbag.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (to Santos) Fuckin' city transferred Sally three months ago out of parking violations into Swayzak's office. Now I gotta pay my own goddamn tickets and she's stuck with an asshole.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Pay more?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (shrugs) No, but there's more exercise -- being chased around a desk.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Aw, I don't believe this shit.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Somebody get a shovel! You seen this, Stephen?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: What?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (reads) "Probationary Fireman Brian McCaffrey, on his very first fire, showed the kind of bravery and courage of a veteran firefighter when he risked life and limb to double-check a burning floor alone, emerging victoriously with Anna Rodriguez, a seamstress for the North Shore Clothing Company... McCaffrey first gained prominence as the subject of a 1972 Pulitzer Prize winning photograph taken at the scene of his father's death..."

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Whadda we gonna do about this?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Y'know, I think it's a union bylaw that if a guy gets in the paper -- especially if it's bullshit -- he owes the company a drink. In fact... (motions to waiter) ...I'll have a double. On the hero.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (confused) What's going on?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Brian McCaffrey, right?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Brian, this is my boss, Alderman Swayzak. (to Swayzak) Brian's a big fan of yours.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. Big fan.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: And I'm a huge fan of what you did to save that woman, Brian.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Uh, I think there's been a mistake. I didn't save that woman.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: No need to be modest, Brian.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: No, you don't understand, I saved a mannequin.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: That really was incredibly work you did. You and your brother, fighting fires together, helluva image, isn't it? You must feel lucky to be assigned under his command.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Every little boy's fantasy.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Brian, let me come to the point. I'd like to offer you a job.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I have a job.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: This one's still with the fire department. One of our best investigators, Don Rimgale, is working on a very difficult, visible case right now. We think he could use another pair of hands and you're exactly the kind of guy I want representing us: An authentic hero from a traditional firefighting clan.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, we got all kinds of traditions -- like dying young.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Not every job in the fire department comes with a tombstone, Brian. This could be a great opportunity to move... beyond a fire engine.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Thanks anyway, Mr. Swayzak, but fire engines sorta run in my family. Politics don't.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: A man suddenly steps between them to pump Swayzak's hand. Brian shakes his head and walks away. Swayzak shoots a concerned glance at Jennifer. She catches up with him at the buffet table.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Across the room, Stephen's at the buffet, watching Helen dance with her fireman date, the drinks hammering him hard.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen gives Pengelly an icy, sideways look.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen smiles and pushes off the bar -- right for Helen as she dances.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Jackson steers her away but Stephen isn't done yet. He dogs them.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen suddenly PUNCHES Jackson.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: And Stephen PLOWS into Jackson. Another fireman JUMPS to Jackson's aid. And Brian's there, defending his brother, PUNCHING OUT a fireman. The crowd finally pulls the two apart.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen takes a step for the bar -- then suddenly turns and JUMPS Jackson again. Brian pulls him off and drags him for the door.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: As Jennifer watches Brian lead Stephen out the door.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Boy, took you all of thirty seconds to blow that.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: C'mon Jennifer, he's just another North-Side jag-off with a mouth.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Brian, do you always have to be so stupid? Think about your future for once.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: So now you suddenly care about my future?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Look, I didn't mean to take a piece out of you back there, I just thought you'd call when you came back. You didn't and... (beat) Don't blow it just because of this garbage between us.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Hey, sorry if I made you look bad in front of your boss. But I'm not gonna be a poster boy for him, I'm trying to do something here. There's five hundred smoke eaters in this room that do that stuff for real every day. Tell Swayzak to talk to one of them.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Aw man, how can she dance with that guy?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I hate that guy. He's a dispatcher. I hate his voice.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Whatever...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I mean, I know women have gotta bang somebody, but why that son of a bitch?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Hey Stevie, he's an asshole...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Uh, Helen, I wanted to talk to you a second about Sean...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Stephen, I'm kinda busy here, can we talk about this later?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: How ya doin', Stephen?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Jackson.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (to Helen) What's wrong with right now? He's your son for christ's sake. He's -- JACKSON Hey, Stephen, what about that dumb ass brother of yours, huh?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: ...Yeah?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Savin' a mannequin... How fuckin' stupid can a guy get?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You can't talk about my brother like that...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (sighs) Here we go...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You're crazy, man!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Leave me alone!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Goddamn it, Stephen, lay off! (Stephen calms a little) You stupid dumbshit, you never know when to fucking quit, do you? You ever wonder why your career's in the fucking toilet? Why you're gonna be stuck a Lt. for life?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: No. (beat) I need a drink.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You don't need a drink, man. You need to get outta here...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (to Swayzak) Ah those McCaffreys... just hate leaving a party with anyone left standing...

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian leads Stephen toward his car.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen pushes Brian away and promptly stumbles to the sidewalk.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian stands there and folds his arms.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian lends an arm.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I'm okay... leave me alone...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: So you got a 'roid going with Jackson or what?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Nah, he's nothin'. It's just sometimes... sometimes you just gotta punch somebody out, y'know?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I don't think I can get up.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Look, Brian, a photographer. Maybe I can get on the cover of LIFE magazine, too.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: C'mon, let's crawl home.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen throws an arm over Brian's shoulder as he leads him up onto the boat.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: ...Adcox, those guys...they don't get it... it isn't the goddamn promotion... or dad... I'm not my old man, y'know? No fire's gonna get me... I don't give a shit about being a captain... it's just... it's just they don't trust me anymore... (blows out painful breath) ...they don't trust me anymore...

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian's flops his brother on the bed. Unties his shoes.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: He clearly can't. Brian slips them off.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: There's just a grim wall lamp above Stephen's face.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian turns off the dim light. Stephen's breathing deepens.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian tucks the blanket around him.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen's voice drifts off into sleep. Brian watches a moment, the rare look of peace on his brother's face, then leaves.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: If you'd get out of my fuckin' way. I could take my own goddamn shoes off...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You're such a pain in the ass... You've always been a pain in the ass...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Jesus, it's too damn bright in here... Like a goddamn spotlight... I'm goin' blind...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (touching light) This?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Yeah... too bright...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: They don't know... they don't know what I hear in there...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: ...This boat could be okay, huh?... Take it out weekends... Sean 'n me...

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Dark and still. Brian, carrying a roll of hose, scales the chain link.

direction.name: direction
