direction.raw_text: Is a practice stand-pipe. Brian counts down to himself, then rushes the stand-pipe, spinning off the cap with a hydrant wrench and attaching the hose coupling. He does it again, over and over.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The sky's gone pink and blue as Brian climbs back over the fence. Adcox, coming out of a donut shop across the street, sees him.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: A truck has JACKKNIFED across the avenue and SPILLED its contents -- several THOUSAND baby chicks. They're scurrying everywhere as Brian's company tries to round them up. It's hopeless as the exhausted firemen stuff handfuls of the cheeping cargo into their turn-out coats. There's ghetto kids all around, grabbing at the chicks, grabbing at the fire engine.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian stops a beat. Rubs his eyes.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian looks at him. Does he mean what he thinks he means? Tim is coming out of a small store across the street. He hands a small bag of groceries to Adcox.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Everyone grows suddenly silent.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (at kids) Hey! Knock it off!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (smiles) Maybe you should have gotten more sleep last night.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: This everything you wanted?

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: A fireman's without even saying so, "Petzold" on the mailbox, Engine 17 parked out front. Brian's alone outside, cleaning the diesel fuel off his arms. Watching a small kid playing with a toy fire truck in the drive.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Tim and Brian are loading the groceries into the fridge. Stephen and Grindle are fixing a loose cabinet door as Adcox sits caulking a faucet fitting at the kitchen table with a young WOMAN.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The sight of uniform is too much for her. Her eyes cloud.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Adcox reaches out and lets her weep on his shoulder.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (to Stephen) Can I help you guys at all?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Nah, we just about got it.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (noticing Adcox's shirt) Sally must be finally ironing your shirts.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: It's just new. Couple'a shifts and it'll be as thrashed as the rest.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: It's okay...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I miss him... I just miss him, y'know?...

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Adcox stands out at the fire engine smoking a cigarette, lost in himself, watching the little boy play with his toy fire truck. Stephen's followed him out.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen leans down close.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: A beat of understanding between them. Stephen looks back at the house.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Adcox can't help but smile.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: This job... This fuckin' job sometimes... To buy it trying to go the extra yard, man, that's one thing, but to buy it just because there wasn't any back-up... it's bullshit...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, it's bullshit. So what? Fuck Swayzak. Fuck 'em all. We don't go into fires for them. You know that. Christ, you taught me that.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You know Knowlton pretty well?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Yeah...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (beat) Kind of an asshole, wasn't he?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Biggest in two battalions.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (beat, smiles) We're gonna be okay, man...

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: As Brian and Tim scrub down the fire engine, the rest of the company lies sprawled in

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Watching a weepy soap. Schmidt walks through and is snared by the TV's glow. He hesitates. Shares the moment.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: A ladderman, WASHINGTON, walks in with a memo.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Everybody clasps Pengelly on the shoulder. "Way to go". "All right, man". Brian turns and sees Stephen out on the apparatus floor, watching. Watches. Pengelly's younger than him.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Is she going to get the divorce?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (sighs with honest concern) Hell if I know, man.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Pengelly, you made the captain's list!

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: An expanse of concrete lying out back of the station. Built in one corner is the concrete shell of a five story training building, just wide enough for a stairway and room on each level. Twenty yards away, Brian, Tim and Adcox stand ready beside a pile of coiled hose rolls.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Tim picks up a roll of hose, 50 pounds, throws it over his shoulder and runs with Adcox to the foot of the building. There's a fixed standpipe that Adcox ties into as Tim drags the other end inside and up a flight of stairs.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian lifts another hose roll under his arm and runs for the building.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian runs up two flights to meet Tim and connect his end. Tim heads down for another roll as Brian drags his up another two flights. It's a bitch. Sweating, he barrels back down the stairs, passing Tim coming up with another roll.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Tim flips him off. Brian laughs and sprints for another roll.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian holds it under his arm and takes off. Stephen grabs a roll himself, hoists it to his shoulder and runs alongside.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian lifts it to his shoulder.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: They come to the doorway. Instead of stopping, Stephen follows Brian in and runs alongside up the stairs. Without a word spoken it's become a race between them. Brian's face explodes in sweat. His heart pounds as they go up flight after flight. The hose rolls weigh a 100 pounds. A thousand. Neck 'n neck all the way; grunting, their throats burning, only one flight from the roof Stephen STUMBLES and SCRAPES his leg. Brian pauses. Stephen's already back on his feet.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian does, Stephen already gaining on him -- getting ready to pass him -- when they burst gasping out onto the roof, Brian the "winner" by a nose. Stephen drops his hose roll, sticks his face into Brian's, -- And laughs. Unsure, Brian starts to join in. Stephen stops suddenly.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Adcox and Tim, down below, have already disappeared back into the station.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: We see now what Stephen apparently doesn't. He was scraped badly, his pant leg torn and leaking dark circles of blood.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen turns and walks away. Brian stands there watching him in blind fury, finally exploding.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: An awkward beat between them that's interrupted suddenly by the station alarm klaxon. Stephen smiles.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (looking at watch) Alright... Go!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Go!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: That isn't a football, probie. Get it on your shoulder.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Having fun, fireman?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You're not breaking any records, Brian.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Your shoulder. Like this!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Come on! Pick it up!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Run, damn you!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Roll the hose.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: What, are you kidding? By myself?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You heard me.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: What, is it the stairs? Christ, I'll let you win next time.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (in Brian's face) You got a problem with drilling, probie?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: No, Lt., I don't have a problem with drilling. But let's just have one drill. Not one for the company and one for me.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Roll the hose.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Goddamn you Stephen, I'm not gonna quit. You hear me!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Well, thank God for fires...

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Smoke and confusion. A MOTHER is screaming hysterically at Stephen as he jumps down from the engine.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen doesn't even pause and enters the building. Brian hesitates a beat, then follows.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (grabbing his coat) My baby! My baby's still up there!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Hang on a sec, Stevie, we got a hoseline coming.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Where they bomb up a staircase just as a WALL OF FIRE LASHES DOWN, KNOCKING them on their ass. Stephen jumps to his feet with an axe as Brian struggles to get up.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen, with just his axe, CHASES up the stairs at the fire, HAMMERING at the flaming boards. The fire retreats into another room, SLAMMING the door shut behind it. Brian struggles up the stairs. The two of them slide up on either side of the closed door, Stephen cradling his axe like a SWAT team shotgun. The door breathes in and out and something animal scratches and snarls on the other side. Brian can feel the panic rising in his throat. That thing behind the door, that slobbering, evil thing. It wants out. It wants... him.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen HAMMERS the lock with his axe and KICKS the door open. A WALL OF FLAME ROARS out past their cheeks, then BACKWASHES in.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen picks up the door, and using it as a shield CHARGES into the flames. Brian tries to follow but the fire WELLS UP, cutting him off. He hesitates. It's that goddamn flame again, leering at him. Daring him. It BUCKS suddenly, DROPPING Brian to his knee. He GROANS in pain.

result.heading: WALL OF FIRE LASHES DOWN, KNOCKING

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Don't take that kind of shit from it! Don't let it know you're scared! Come on!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Ready?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Christ, Stephen, let's wait for the hose team...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Listen to it, Brian... Jump when I say... It won't get us.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Now!

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: And now Adcox and Grindle are coming up the stairs with a hoseline WASHING DOWN the room. Clouds of furious steam bellow out and across the ceiling. Nobody could be alive in there. Except Stephen. His entire outfit smoldering, he emerges from the clouds like a fucking god, carrying in one arm a gasping child.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Most of the firemen have gathered together for post-fire coffee and stories. Brian sits off alone on the fire engine bumper, apart from them. Santos walks up.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen walks up. Sits down beside him.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian lingers only a moment before standing.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian hands Stephen his helmet and walks away.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: They think she's gonna live...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You okay?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I waited... I would have fucking waited...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: That's not what it's about, Brian. The point is there was a kid in there. And what if there'd been two? I went in because that's what I do. It's my way. It's dad's way. It isn't everybody's way.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Dad's way? Where did he tell you that? In a fucking seance?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You said you wanted to know something, Brian. What did you learn today? (Brian doesn't answer) What do you say, Brian, huh? Time to move on?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You're right, Stephen... You win... You're the best, man...

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: There's only six like it in city hall, and this one has a view.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (on intercom) Brian McCaffrey on line two for Jennifer.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I'll take it in my office.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (turns to her and smiles) Go get him.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Jennifer comes out of Swayzak's office and walks down to her own.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: . BRIAN'S APARTMENT - DAY -- It's a tiny, bleak little rat hole. She picks up the receiver...

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: We see Brian in his apartment.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian hangs up. He stares at it a moment, then SLAMS it against the wall. Jennifer stares at the phone with something almost like sadness.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Brian?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I've been thinking about what you said the other night... If the offer's still on the table, I'd like to talk about it.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (beat) ...Okay. I'll arrange things with your assignment captain. (beat) Marty's a good man, Brian.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Yeah...

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen drives past the burned-out brownstone that fried Alan Seagrave. He parks in the alley behind, walks up the building, and PULLS OFF a plywood sheet covering a blown-out window.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen walks through the creepy, brutalized silence. Back to where Rimgale had focused his investigation that night. He searches the floor, the wall, looking for something...

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: A crumbling one in Chinatown. Brian checks the address on his slip of paper. He stands there a beat, hating himself.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: It's a regular station but for the rear that has been converted into arson squad offices. As Brian approaches the office door he can see Rimgale sitting at his desk. Standing nervously beside it is a fresh-faced, uniformed PROBIE.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The kid is dying a thousand deaths of humiliation.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The kid shuffles off hang-dog. Rimgale's angry gaze falls on Brian.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: And Rimgale walks into his office, leaving Brian marooned in the doorway. Stepping behind a small partition, Rimgale changes his shirt. Brian can just glimpse from where he stands a horrible burn that has consumed most of Rimgale's stomach. Rimgale catches the look.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale glances at his watch, puts on his coat, and picks up a small paper bag.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (to probie) ...So stop me if I get this wrong... The fire's almost out... You're upstairs on the unburned floor checking for heat. You've been told by your Battalion Chief, your Captain, by me, not to do anything up there until ordered. But now the itch starts, and all of a sudden comes the Glory Boy Flash: Hey, I'm a hero. Heroes don't just stand around. So on your own you decided to punch out a window for ventilation. Was that before or after you noticed you were standing in a lake of gasoline?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You could've crispered half your company with that little stunt, but more importantly you wrecked the physical evidence I use to prove it's arson. You've made my day longer, Probie. Go home and think about that.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Uh, I'm Brian McCaffrey. Your new assistant.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Your Dennis' kid. (beat) I work alone.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Are you still here?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Get used to me, Inspector. I'm not going anywhere.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Then go find a corner. I don't want you in my way.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I think we should get something straight here. I was assigned to this office by the city.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Look, I knew your father, he had a helluva reputation on this job. But that don't mean you get any slack. Swayzak sends you down here, okay, I gotta eat you, that's the rules and I got nothing to say about that. But Swayzak or no, you live with me. Step out of line, and I don't care who knows you, I'll swing the hammer. (beat) You think you're the first?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Where are you going?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Pest control.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: And the face of RONALD, an unremarkable man in his 40s. Unremarkable but for laser eyes and two heavily bandaged hands. Go wide and find him sitting in an institutional chair -- handcuffed, actually -- in an institutional hall. A uniformed guard stands nearby as Brian and Rimgale come down the corridor. Ronald smiles upon seeing Rimgale.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Ronald's eyes pick up Brian's name on his prison ID badge.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale silences Brian with a threatening hand.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The cop helps Ronald to his feet and all four are marching down the hall.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Shadow.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: How ya doin', Ronald. Staying comfortable?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Didn't think you'd make it.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Wouldn't miss this for the world, pal.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (looking at Brian) Who's this?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: He works for me.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Is he a fireman? (smiles) I like firemen.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You like everybody, Ronald.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Brian McCaffrey... (eyes light up happily) Oh this is really a treat. Brian McCaffrey. Lost a dad to the animal, huh?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (heating up) Hey, do I know you?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You don't know him.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I know you.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (to Ronald) What the hell are you talking about my --

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Knock it off. Now.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Tell him about me, Shadow?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Ronald here likes telephones. Used to tape wooden matches to the bell striker and wrap it in cotton. Came up with a whole little thing there, didn't you Ronald? When you got bored, what did you do? You just started making calls... mostly day care centers and retirement homes, wasn't it?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Did he tell you how we finally met?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Nobody cares, Ronald.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Oh, but it's a good story, Shadow. You're depriving our famous young friend here...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Okay... Ronald Bowland...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: It was on State Street, right?... Just your basic warehouse torch for the owner. Cakewalk. But the animal... turned on me... 'Ol Shadow here, he shows up -- whole place is going like hell -- my hair, my hands... could've just let the animal take me -- but Shadow, he's a good camper, so he tries to pull 'ol Ronald out. Guess he didn't notice the tub of phosphorous next to me... (smiles) Notice you're still a little shy about rolling your sleeves up, Shadow. Show him your stomach yet?

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Ronald in the hot seat before a parole board, Rimgale and Brian on the sidelines.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The parole board shuffles their papers. It's a done deal. Rimgale suddenly stands and approaches Ronald.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: A tortured look comes over Ronald's face. He's holding back. From the paper bag, Rimgale suddenly tosses a burned baby doll in his lap.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale then lights a cigarette lighter in Ronald's face.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The parole board stares, stunned. Rimgale stands.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: ...All right, the parole board has received Mr. Bowland's fitness report, his ID-44, endorsement from his section warden... Dr. Norris?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: As supervising psychiatrist I would describe Mr. Bowland's progress as remarkable. Taking into account his disability and the six years already served, I recommend parole.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Bowland, do you regret your crimes?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Yes. I understand now the pain I caused.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: If released, will you commit these crimes again?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I won't.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Do you consider yourself ready for society?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Yes.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Sure Ronald? You're ready alright.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Absolutely.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (surprised) Excuse me, Mr. Rimgale.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me. (to Ronald) What do you do with little girls?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: What do you do with them, Ronald? Huh?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (smiles)

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Burn them.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: And old ladies?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Burn them.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: And the world -- the whole world.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (smiles)

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Burn it all.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: See ya next year, Ronald. Gotta go.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: A pre-war theatre closed with a sign: UNDER RENOVATION -- OPENING XMAS 1991. DAVID BENTON, mid-forties, climbs out of his car and walks to the entrance with some rolled-up blueprints.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Benton walks through the vast theatre and up to a beautiful Art Noveau office door: DAVID BENTON, PRIVATE. He goes to insert his key. Drops it. As he reaches down, we see a tiny wisp of smoke SUCK back under the door. Benton sniffs, as if he smells something, then shrugs and inserts his key. It'd have been a good story if he'd lived longer. The moment he pushes the door open It EXPLODES OUTWARD in a ROARING FIREBALL.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Later and engine companies have already knocked down the building fire as Brian climbs out of Rimgale's red sedan.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: He starts handing Brian handfuls of equipment cases. Loaded down, Brian follows Rimgale into the building.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (opens trunk) Hey kid, c'mere -- At least make yourself useful.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Fire crews are at work in here, including Engine 17 at the other end of the theatre. Brian's surprised to see them, his eyes locking briefly with Stephen's. An ENGINE COMPANY LT. walks up to Rimgale.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: "Him" is our previous owner, David Benton, just his hands and a leg showing from under the collapsed door. Rimgale crouches beside it.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian does. The corpse's keys are still in the lock. So's Benton. Blown with such force he seems fused with the door. On the door's edge Rimgale notices a small patch of melted, sticky goo. With his penknife he scrapes a sample and seals it in a glass vial, stands, and walks into the office.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: We were lucky with this one. Could've taken out the whole complex, but the explosion blew out most of the flame. Good for us. (looks to body)

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Not so good for him.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Turn this over.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: What do you want me to do with -- Rimgale, now inside, silences him with an outstretched arm.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale doesn't answer. His eyes drift over the scorched walls as he speaks softly to them.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: He scratches at some soot. Smiles and lifts a small hand recorder.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian pulls it aside. The lower third of the wall is completely untouched by soot.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: There's some on the sill of a blown window. Brian hands a shard to Rimgale, who turns it over in his palm.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale turns to the wall, a section where the plaster is severely damaged. He probes with a penknife.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale follows the damaged wall down -- down -- to a melted wall socket.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian chops it out from the wall. Rimgale crouches down, peels back the melted faceplate and examines the wires. The copper tip is severely melted. Rimgale sniffs the plug.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale shuts off the recorder. Stares down Brian.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale opens a plastic bag and puts the plug inside.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale stands and walks out.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Shhh.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (after a beat) What are you listening to?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You sneaky little son of a bitch... Hide and seek... Come on, tell me what I want to know...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (business-like into recorder) Heavy smoke stains observed in entry room. Demarkation line high. Fire never got hot enough here to cook soot off. It started somewhere else... (walks down hall) Less soot here. More heat. (they enter back room) And very little soot here. (to Brian) Get that couch out of the way.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (to himself) So you were happy here. Warm and cozy and in no hurry... (into recorder) Soot high, clean unburned wall low, indicates slow burn in thermal balance. (to Brian) Find me some glass.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Glass?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Do we have a language barrier here? Glass.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (into recorder) Glass found in ignition room is in small, thin pieces, indicating explosion. Lack of discoloration indicates a long, slow burn. Explosion must of come after a slow burn. (shuts recorder off) You little tease... What were you up to you little bastard, huh? What made you that mad? (then, an idea) Or scared. (switches on recorder) It started in this room. Took its time, hung out... but the air ran out. It couldn't breathe. So it was snuffed. But it wasn't dead... still all that trapped heat, lying low, waiting for some sucker to open the door and give it that one gulp of air...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Another backdraft.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Finish coat burned away... Severe spawling of rough coat...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: That's our ignition point. Dig it out. Carefully.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (into recorder) Temperature in this room was about 2000 degrees, but copper wire in outlet is melted, which requires 5000 degrees. An accidental short in the plug could of created a spark of 7000 degrees, hot enough to melt the wire and start a fire.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: No it couldn't.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I mean you'd be right -- with normal wire. But that's gauge ten in that plug -- industrial stuff. Who knows why they put it in here -- but it won't melt at less than 12,000 degrees. And no natural spark short of lightning gets that hot. (Rimgale just stares) In another life I was in high-end electronics.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (into recorder) Have outlet analyzed for any traces of flammable accelerants.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Don't mention it.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian follows Rimgale down from the office into the vast theatre. Walls hiss and spit. Brian's surprised to see his former engine mates there, tromping and crunching their way through broken glass, their flashlights like dancing fireflies. Tim passes by.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Everybody turns at the voice and the air suddenly chills.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: And Rimgale's off to another room. Brian turns and looks at the wall. It's endless.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Silence. Brian looks over the wall. A dirty puddle separates him from it.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Grindle stares at him a beat, then wordlessly steps into the muck and pulls free a section of wall, dropping it on the ground in front of Brian. Santos and Grindle look at each other.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: There's a pike pole leaning against the wall. Brian pulls it aside. SPLASH -- The pole had been supporting a small, sagging piece of ceiling that instantly collapses, dumping twenty gallons of murky, putrid black water all over Brian's civvys. Nobody laughs.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen appears around the corner. Sees what's happened.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: They leave. Brian stands there, humiliated.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian burns with shame and anger as Adcox walks away. Stephen hands Brian a towel.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian snatches it from him. Glares at his brother.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian walks away. Stephen calls after him.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Tim.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (distant) Brian.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (to Brian) Check the wall for burn patterns.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (to Tim) So, you surviving without me?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: There's no replacement 'cause of your boss' cuts, if that's what you mean. If someone else goes out on an injury we're really screwed.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Swayzak's not my boss.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (to Brian) Ooooh, like the tie. Love the tie.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Grindle, scrape down that wall for me, huh? I would myself, but the tie 'n all, y'know...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Uh, Brian, if you're lookin' for smoke patterns, there's some good ones over here.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Yeah? Where?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (as Brian walks over) Little to the right... further... further... Right behind there. Hey, could you hand me that pike pole?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Sorry, maybe that wasn't it after all.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: That's just about enough, guys, okay?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: See ya around, Brian.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (to Brian) What the hell's the matter with you, huh? You're steppin' in the shit again. You could've done it. You don't want this. (the suit 'n tie) Wake up, kid.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Here. Dry yourself off.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Look, you are sorta making yourself fair game.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Thanks for the insight.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Brian, look -- BRIAN Just leave me alone, okay?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Bri... Rimgale's okay. I don't get half the shit he's talking about, but then everybody says the same thing about me. Who the hell knows?

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Helen, Stephen's ex-wife, is sitting at her kitchen when she looks up suddenly at a strange sound coming from the roof.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: On the short, sloping roof, Stephen stands hammering a shingle back into place. Helen sticks her head out the dormer window.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: He stops and tosses the hammer aside. Looks at his watch.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: But she smiles.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen sighs deeply.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: He sighs and hops down from the roof to the driveway.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: She watches him as he walks lonely up the street.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Stephen, what are you doing here?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Fixing my roof.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: It's not your roof anymore.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Where's Sean?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: He's got piano lessons.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Oh yeah? How's he doing?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: He's going to be a fireman.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Give up, babe. You can't fight it. Believe me, my mom tried...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (beat) Stephen, you gotta stop just showing up on the roof like this.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I just wanted to, I don't know, not exactly apologize for the other night -- especially since I don't remember much of it -- HELEN -- You remember.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Yeah... I just thought I should say, I don't know, something.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: The great communicator.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Sorry I hit Jackson.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: He deserved it. He was born deserving it.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: He treats you okay?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Okay.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I treated you better.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You treated me like shit.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You want some coffee?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Coffee? Nah, I gotta go.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: What's wrong, Stephen? (looks at her) C'mon, you only beat up the roof when something's on your mind. (beat) How's Brian doing?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: He's out.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I know he's out, but how's he doing?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Y'know, I treated him better than any other probie I ever had. He probably hates my guts, but I did the best thing for him. I made him finally look in the mirror.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Ah Stephen, that's what this is really about, isn't it? You always have to be right.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Hey, I'm the first one to admit when I'm wrong.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Yeah? When was the last time?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: In a fire? Never. (beat) Look, I'm his brother. I care about him, y'know? He was going to get himself killed. Maybe not today, maybe not in a year, but it would've happened. And I couldn't -- I just couldn't...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You can't keep being his father...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You know what I realized today? I can't remember my dad's face anymore. There's pictures of him staring at me everywhere I go, but the guy behind them... he's gone...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I'll see ya around, Helen.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Lab Tech, RICCO, leads Brian and Rimgale through the autopsy area till they come on two corpses lying side by side covered in plastic.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: If you say so. Brian's stomach does a half-gainer as he's confronted by two hideously charred bodies.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian is discreetly avoiding his gaze, whistling quietly to himself as he looks over specimen jars on a shelf.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Ricco lifts Benton's charred shoulder. Underneath we see some of his clothes that have melted and co-mingled with his flesh.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: A credit card has been fried right into Cosgrove's skin about where his back pocket should have been.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Ricco erupts in a honking laugh, then switches instantly back to a business tone.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: With supreme reluctance Brian pulls the crisper's head and shoulder away from the table.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian gathers the torso up and hoists him higher.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: At that instant, Cosgrove's eyes OPEN and his body SIGHS. Brian DROPS the body in shock and backs away, stunned.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Okay, Alan Seagrave and Donald Cosgrove...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: ...Both deaths due to close encounters with stationary objects; office door for Mr. Cosgrove, '89 Porsche for Mr. Seagrave. No non-relevant traumas. No significant blood toxicology. Attitude of both trajectories consistent with explosions.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: They ran the residue you scraped from both crispers' front doors. It's a combination of plumber's putty and rayophene gum. Burns almost completely away when you light it.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Putty? On both doors?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: There's something else kinda interesting...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: See this?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Guess he didn't leave home without it.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Anyway, down here, take a look...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: McCaffrey, hold this for us.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Uh, I don't think that's in my contract...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I just re-wrote your contract. C'mere...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Jesus Christ, he isn't gonna try to sell you insurance, lift him.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (to Rimgale) See that patch of shirt? We wondered about the discoloration so he ran a spectro. On a lucky shot we picked up some traces of Trychticholorate. Nobody around here had ever heard of it.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Trychticholorate? Alright, it's an absorption catalyst in toxic waste accidents. It's pretty rare, they stopped making it a couple'a years ago.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Probably got in Cosgrove's clothes in a gas state from the fire.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: What the hell was it doing in the fire?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: That's your job.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I asked you to hold him, not feel him up...

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale's FD sedan. Brian is still wringing imaginary guts off his hands. Rimgale tosses an open fire chem book in his lap.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale CLAPS his hands next to Brian's head, STARTLING him.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale looks at Brian. He's getting tired of this.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Read.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: "Trychtichlorate is a binary structured --" SHADOW -- Go to the bottom. Under heat properties.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: "During heat episodes of 2000 Kelvin or higher, Trych breaks down and dissipates. Will consume magnesium".

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Ever burned magnesium? It's so hot it takes water molecules and BAMM!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Son of a bitch tears 'em apart just to eat the oxygen. Wouldn't take much at all to melt ten gauge wire. Problem's burnt magnesium leaves a powder trace -- unless you could find something that would eat its residue.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Trychticholorate. Then Swayzak can announce Seagrave was a murder.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Look, it isn't proof, okay? Someone may have put the chemical in the outlet, but we found it as a vapor in Cosgrove's clothes.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: And the putty around the door?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Even if it was used to seal the air off, that doesn't explain why someone would go to the trouble of a backdraft. A gun's a helluva lot easier

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: But the right guess on this is arson.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I don't guess.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Some people say you don't do much of anything when it comes to this case.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I don't work for them, either.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian's sitting at a desk. He's finishing up a huge paper clip Tyrannosaurus. The phone RINGS.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: We see Jennifer's calling from her office, she's busy signing papers brought to her and okaying campaign posters as she talks.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: He tosses a paper airplane.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian hangs up quickly and walks back into

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Arson.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Straightest answer your department's given me all week.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Hey.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: How's it going?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Boss and I are up to about three words an hour.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (to secretary) Green committed to a thousand. (to Brian) There's another fund-raising party tonight. Marty'd really like you to come.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I don't know, I'm kinda swamped here.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I could use a date.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Yeah? Well, maybe I can fit it in...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: McCaffrey! Come here!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (into phone) Call ya back.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale's there, crouched excitedly beside a trash can that's lid's been sealed closed. He tamps a piece of putty on the rim and backs away.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian walks over and RIPS OFF the lid. -- Instantly a tongue of flame SHOOTS straight up past his head and BLOWS out.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale's grinning like a little kid.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Take the top off. Go ahead. Take it off.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Jesus!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: That's it! Oh, that son of a bitch, he's different, goddamn it! You see what this tells us, huh? Our killer doesn't love fire!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: What?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (pulls out file) I got it after we talked to Ronald. Torches. Want to fry the whole goddamn world. But the fires that killed those guys never really burned up much. -- The burns were all lit in outlets surrounded by double firebreaks in the walls. And he made his burns backdrafts. ([p. 78])

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: But he killed these guys.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: But he could have killed everybody there. The firebreaks kept it from spreading in the wall. The backdraft blew out the flame. That's it. That's the reason.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: What reason?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Why backdrafts. Whoever fried Seagrave and Cosgrove went to a helluva lot of trouble to make sure they died by fire, but also made sure the fire blew itself out.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: That's why the sealant on the doors... So what have we got, a torch with a conscience?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: No, we have a stone killer trying to make a point.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Are you going public with this?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: No. Do that and I guarantee you'll scare him off. I don't want him running away.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Latin band cuts loose as beautiful people mill about against a beautiful Chicago skyline. An AIR HORN blows, and suddenly the skyline is MOVING. We're on a huge, private party boat.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian's leaning on the boat railing watching the passing parade of rich and beautiful. Across the sea of champagne and brie, he spots Jennifer talking with her boss, Swayzak. He has his hand on her back. Jennifer spots Brian. She smile, detaches herself and walks over.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Swayzak suddenly appears with his entourage.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Swayzak swings around and puts his arm cheesily around Brian's shoulder. Another staffer slaps a SWAYZAK FOR MAYOR sticker to Brian's lapel. Jennifer rolls her eyes to Brian. I'm sorry... Snap.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Swayzak leads her off in pursuit. Left alone, Brian turns to the railing, stares off at the passing city. You can hear the wind-up of a siren. And there it is now, an engine company zooming along Wacker Drive. Something digs and kicks inside of Brian as he watches it disappear.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: She's appeared again beside him.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Hi.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (eyes on Swayzak) Hey... (beat) So are you dating your boss or what?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: If you weren't at least the 300th person to ask me that, I'd probably be pissed. (beat, sighs) Boy, you sure know it's a man's world sometimes...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Sorry. (beat) Are you dating anyone?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You think that's really any of your business?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Well, you did invite me here.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Marty did. (beat, smiles) But I wanted you to come to.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Mr. McCaffrey...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Nice boat.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: It isn't mine. (to photographer) Let's get a picture.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (seeing someone else) Larry! (sotto to Jennifer) What does he do again?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: How's the job going?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Okay.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Boy, Rimgale's as slow as a snail, isn't he?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: No, he's more of a dinosaur. Guy's not a dummy, though. He's juggling alot of balls on this one.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, but it doesn't take Albert Einstein just to figure out if these guys were killed by accidents or not.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Jesus, give him a break. There isn't enough proof yet to go public. Sure, we found some chemical shit we think somebody dumped in the plugs to torch 'em, and we've maybe figured out why backdrafts, but you can't rush this stuff. Not 'till it's locked.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: But Rimgale's probably going to come around to arson.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: In a dinosaur kinda way, yeah.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: ! Both of them look up sharply. A woman drunk out of her mind has tipped over in her chair. She laughs, her fellow tablemates laugh, everybody laughs. Jennifer takes Brian by the arm in the opposite direction and smiles.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Save me.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The band's completely cut loose now. A wild percussion rhythm that has everyone on their feet dancing like madmen. Brian and Jennifer stomp and sweat and shake and giggle through hair crazily askew. The lakeshore is twinkling and wonderful as it slips past. The drums beat faster and harder and the only thing that isn't moving now is their eyes -- eyes locked on each other.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Sweaty, flushed with the evening and a few drinks, Brian and Jennifer pull up in her car.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Thanks for the invite.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Got anything to drink in there?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Oh, there might be something stashed away for emergencies.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The regular engine company's gone to bed and the arson squad's packed in for the night, leaving the apparatus floor quiet and dim as Brian and Jennifer enter. Brian leads her back past the engine and arson sedan to the rear where Rimgale has his offices. As they walk Jennifer's eyes drift up to the old sculpted parapets, the press-tin ceiling.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: This is one of the oldest fire stations in the city. Lotta tradition locked up in here. What do you think?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Homey.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: See that trap door up there? That used to lead to the hay loft when they had horse-drawn engines. It was pretty different then... but kinda the same, y'know?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Do you miss it? (he doesn't answer) You seem like you do.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: When I came back, I knew more than anything else that I wanted to be a fireman.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Then why did you quit?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I wanted to be a good one.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: They walk into the back arson offices. Brian pokes through a few drawers, one or two shelves. Finally he lifts a squat, specialized fire extinguisher. The bottom has been hollowed out, leaving room for a fifth of bourbon.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: He pours her a glass. Jennifer takes a generous sip of her's, turns, brushes past him and breathes,

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Old firehouse trick.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: So show me your fire truck.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian escorts Jennifer along the side of the behemoth.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian lifts a narrow, tapered straight-bore nozzle.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Beat. The air cracks between them. And is brushed aside. In an instant they're all over each other. Tangled lips and gulping breaths. Jennifer abruptly breaks it off

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Well, our specimen here is your basic standard issue piece of primary suppression equipment. This area is the pumping panel, which controls the rate of liquid insertion into the hose.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Uh huh.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: This is a six inch playpipe, cast bronze to keep it firm during hard flows. (picks up another item) This is our pipe extender, used in forward lays... (moves on) This is our hard suction line... Our adjustable insertion nozzle... (comes around back of trunk) ...And this is the hose bed.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: And looks mischievously up at the hose bed, with its long curling rolls of soft cotton. Brian doesn't remember this precise scenario being discussed at the academy, but he improvises admirably, popping up onto the hose bed and offering a gentlemanly hand to Jennifer. As they tumble into the soft folds

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Engine 17 roars up, lights flashing, to a high-rise. As the crew jumps down Tim trips and falls flat on his face.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Jesus Tim, if you're going to kill yourself at least wait till the fire, it's better P.R.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Jennifer unbuttons Brian's shirt.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: She pulls the shirt off his shoulder as we

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Tell me about the playpipe again...

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Engine 17 walking up to a frazzled security guard in the lobby.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: They climb into the elevator.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Where is it?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Don't know. There's alarms going off on three different floors.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Wonderful.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: It's cramped on the way up with the bulky coats, helmets, hose rolls, and the tangible nervousness that always goes with this kind of fire. The elevator Musak plays 101 Strings version of "Tie A Yellow Ribbon 'Round The Old Oak Tree".

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: How do we know if the floor's going to be on fire?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: If the doors open and it's hot, don't get out.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian pulls off Jennifer's stockings. As she kicks it away...

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The elevator stops. DING. The door opens. No howling blaze, not even any noise, but enough hanging smoke that you can't see your hand in front of your face. They fan out gingerly onto the floor, looking for the fire. Hide and seek in a white fog bank. Everybody stops and listens. Slowly, carefully, they feel their way through the haze.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: On cue something snakes past behind the walls, whispers and whines and shivers up and over them and then is silent. Grindle attaches a hoseline to the building standpipe.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: But Stephen's on the hunt now. Obsessed.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen and Tim take the lead, their axes gripped like shotguns. Grindle backs them up with a charged hoseline.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Adcox folds. With a stricken look on his face he takes his crew down the other way. Stephen and Tim slowly feel their way.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: It's here.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: These high-rise gigs give me the creeps.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Let's wait for a back-up, Stephen. We're early on this one, it hasn't even broke out yet. We're one short as it is with Brian gone.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Want to learn something?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Yes sir!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Adcox, go with Pengelly and check the other side.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: It isn't safe, man. Don't go splittin' us up. Not with this one.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: What the hell's the matter with you? You always check the other side. I haven't got time for bullshit right now, okay? We got a job here.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Let me take the lead, Stephen...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Goddamn it Adcox! Just do your fucking job!

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Everybody SPINS around in terror. Nothing. Something inhuman giggles down ahead of them. Stephen smiles.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Tim looks confused. He doesn't get it. They come to a side door. Stephen runs his hand down the jam, feels for heat. Then he steps back, takes a deep breath, and CRASHES the door down with one AXE BLOW. Quiet inside.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (like a mantra) Oh, you're so very sly, but so am I... (to Tim) ...Listen to it... you can tell when a wall cracks which way it's gonna jump... you can hear the doors breathe if they're hot...

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian and Jennifer are into the rhythm now, breathing deeply. On the wall above them are framed photos of dead firemen. Watching.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen concentrates on the sound of the fire above him, -- then abruptly turns and CRASHES down another door.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian and Jennifer lie in a tight embrace, enjoying the moment, the lull, as suddenly the lights SNAP ON and an alarm klaxon BELLOWS. Firemen are coming down the pole now.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: They frantically climb into their clothes. The firemen haven't noticed them as they climb aboard. They've STARTED THE ENGINE.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: What's going on?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: What are they doing?

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: And before either of them realizes it, they're suddenly pulling out into the street and WAILING off down the block. The wind's wild in their hair, the siren deafening, the flashing red lights blinding staccato, And Jennifer loves it. She kisses Brian fiercely, he lets out a war whoop lost in the blast of air, and together they hold each other as the night screams past and...

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Engine 17 pulls up into the parking lot of the high-rise fire. Firemen leap out of the cab and rush around behind to pull off lengths of hose from the bed. As the folds curl away the fireman is stunned to see a woman's stocking come out with it. With equal shock he looks up and watches as a disheveled and grinning Brian and Jennifer climb calmly down out of the bed.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Excuse us.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen and Tim creep along the hall.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Tim's come to one.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen BANGS down another door. Sticks his head in to check. A little woodpecker toy dips up and down in a glass of water. Tim readies his axe before his door, gathers his courage as Stephen comes out of the room he was checking. Sees Tim lifting his axe.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Tim doesn't hear. The axe is already up.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Tim's committed now, coming hard at the door. And Stephen sees it for just an instant -- Small tendrils of smoke edging lazily around the door -- then being sucked back in.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: He rushes for Tim as Tim's axe SMACKS the door and a whine behind it builds and roars and howls and Tim's all follow- through now, hitting the door with his shoulder as The door EXPLODES OUTWARD, HURLING TIM against the opposite wall and for an instant he's okay but he freezes in terror as A SHRIEKING TONGUE OF FLAME SHOOTS OUT THE DOORWAY and Grindle shouts in horror and opens his hose line as the flames wrap Tim like a jealous lover as Adcox hears it and screams,

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: And Tim's screaming now too, because his helmet, his mask, his face, it's all melting and Grindle dives suicidally at the monster, BLASTING it with his hose as Stephen ignores the flames and puts his arms around Tim as Grindle DOUSES them both, killing the flames. The monster rolls wounded back into the room, into the air shafts as Tim whimpers incoherently, sliding down the wall as Stephen tries to help but oh God you can't tell what's face and what's mask and helmet anymore. Grindle looks back where the fire came from. There's a corpse in there, burned and lying between two doors. Adcox rushes to Tim's side sobbing and it's the end, the end of the goddamn world...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (to Tim) Lotta smoke, but it isn't rolling... that means it's hiding... staying sleepy... one of these doors...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (to himself) Easy... no hurry... you're not going anywhere...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Did you check the door for heat, Tim?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Tim?

result.heading: A SHRIEKING TONGUE OF FLAME SHOOTS OUT THE DOORWAY

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Tim!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Oh God! Oh God no!

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian and Jennifer are having the time of their lives, when suddenly a group of firemen pass by rushing someone on a stretcher to an ambulance and Brian sees -- sweet Jesus -- it's Tim. Jennifer turns away in horror. They load Tim into the van as Adcox and Grindle jump in to ride along. To hold his hand. Stephen watches the ambulance disappear out into the street. Frustration and fury tear at him as he takes off his coat and slams it to the ground. He kicks it, kicks it till his strength's gone. He turns, his wounded eyes finding Brian.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale walks down the smokey corridor. The charred civilian is there, sitting in the short stretch of hall between two blown doors. Through the haze Rimgale sees Stephen crouched in the interior room, picking at the debris. Lost in himself.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen stands and looks around the room, seemingly unaware of Rimgale. He walks wordlessly straight out past him, his eyes streaming with tears.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Stevie.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian shoulders his way through the emergency room. He passes a small alcove full of vending machines. Adcox is there, sipping a paper cup, leaning against the machine in deep anguish.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Is he...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: He's alive.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Further down the hall is ICU. Grindle and Santos are there, sitting outside the room, raw and weary. Grindle nods to Brian. Everyone's still stained and smudged from the fire. Everyone but Brian. Brian looks through a door window into the room. There, surrounded by doctors and physicians, lies Tim. He's been cut out of his uniform. Gauze bandages everywhere. As a pair of forceps peel some away Brian glimpses what used to be a face, now only reds and browns and leaky whites. He turns away.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Voices rise down the hall. Turn to shouts. It's Adcox and Stephen, tearing heartbreakingly into one another. Brian can't make out the words but it's ugly, emotional. Abruptly it ends and Stephen emerges from the alcove, walking toward them upset.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen's got other things on his mind.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian grabs his arm. Stephen SNAPS and roughly PUSHES Brian, knocking him against the wall. Brian comes off it in a flash and is all over Stephen. They go down and it's all thrashing and shouting now. A horrible, endless draw. Grindle and Santos are in it, pulling them apart, holding them up against opposite walls. Both brothers glare at one another, tears filling their eyes. Brian shakes Grindle off and walks away.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Do they think he'll pull through?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: They're not saying.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I should have been there.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: None of us should have been there, Brian.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You had to do it, didn't you?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: ...Not now, Brian.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Had to take on another fire bare- handed, huh? Had to be fucking myth man in there instead of looking out for your probie. Is that what happened? Is it, Stephen?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I had that fire. He didn't listen!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: He didn't listen? He was a fucking candidate! He was your responsibility. He shouldn't have been there in the first place, Stephen. (beat) You burned him.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Fuck you.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian sits staring blankly. A newspaper drops in front of him. FIRE DEPT. SAYS IT'S MURDER. Rimgale stands above him.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian's eyes wince closed.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Goes on about how the break was made through the discovery of "chemical traces" and a "behavioral link". Oh, and Swayzak's quoted saying the chief investigator is closing in on the torch and expects an arrest "any time".

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Get your stuff and get out.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: She's pouring some coffee as Brian bursts in.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Swayzak appears in the doorway. He looks haggard, as if he hasn't slept. There's something haunted in his eyes.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian shoulders his way past Swayzak and walks out.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (surprised) Brian. What's wrong?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You told Swayzak about our arson lead. It's all over the fucking news.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I didn't know it was a secret. There aren't supposed to be secrets between the city and its investigators -- BRIAN -- Bullshit! You knew what I told you wasn't ready for the papers -- JENNIFER Will you please keep your voice down, there's people -- BRIAN -- You could have scared the son of a bitch off. We may never bust him now. All for a couple's political points.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I was doing my job.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (grabs her arm) Yeah? And just how much of all this has been "doing your job"?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (shakes it off) Let me ask you something, do you really think Marty had you assigned to arson because of your firefighting skills? Who the hell are you kidding? I was there, remember? I saw you and your brother -- BRIAN Leave Stephen out of this -- JENNIFER Oh yeah, he's the real fireman. (beat) Who are you? Just another probie working for Swayzak -- BRIAN -- I work for the city.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You knew what we were asking you to do. Don't suddenly pull out a conscience now. The fit isn't right.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Mr. McCaffrey... Keeping busy?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. In fact, I just dropped off a letter to the Times explaining how yesterday's arson announcement was a fabrication by your office. They loved it. And you know what? You were right, my family background in firefighting gave it weight.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Oh Brian...

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian walks up to Tim's room. Stephen's sitting there, ragged looking. Inside the young probie lies wrapped in tubes and gauze and years of wasted promise. An EKG beeps, a respirator hisses, and Brian gulps down something heavy in his throat.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen walks away.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: He's gonna live. Maybe not much else, but he's gonna live...

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: As Rimgale gets out of his car a limousine pulls up. Swayzak opens the rear door from inside.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Inspector.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Alderman.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Cruising through traffic. Swayzak is disheveled, unshaven, fidgety. A man who hasn't slept and had a few drinks before the one he's pouring now. He offers one to Rimgale.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Swayzak apparently doesn't.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: For the first time, Rimgale sees real fear on Swayzak's face.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The sedan stops back at arson HQ. They'd gone around the block.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I usually have breakfast first.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: When are you going to catch the prick that's doing this, Don?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: "Don?"

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Don't you have any leads at all?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: No Marty, I don't.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: We still haven't found a connection between the victims.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Jesus, open your eyes! Seagrave, Cosgrove, and now Holcomb -- fried in a goddamn high-rise!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Holcomb? I didn't know the name of that victim had even been released yet.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale opens the door, climbs out, lingers.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The door shuts and Swayzak roars away.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Is there a connection between them, Alderman?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Just catch the son of a bitch.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale walks back into his offices. He's surprised to see Brian there working at his desk.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale stares at Brian, appraises him.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: What the hell are you doing here?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I'm finished with Swayzak. I'll do whatever you want me to do. I just want to help catch the guy that burned Tim. You gotta give me another shot.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: . HIGH-RISE A CLOSE UP of Rimgale POPPING the molding around the door frame of Holcomb's burned office. Underneath can be seen traces of the same white residue from the other fires.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale rubs the white powder between his fingers.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale stands at the spot in the short hall where the body lied between two doors.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian steps into the inner office.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian begins searching, probing. He finally stands. Defeated.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian's eyes don't understand. From Rimgale's coat comes a plastic flask. He pours out of it a liquid onto the floor and lights a match.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale drops the match.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I thought 'ol Marty was acting a little strange... And he's right.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Backdraft?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: The backdraft was set somewhere in there. It fried Holcomb when he opened the inner door. But the outer door held... and waited for Tim...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: So find me the fire.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You're thinking too much of the building and not enough of the ghost.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: In a word, Brian, what is this job all about?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Fire.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: . A small flame explodes to life.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The fire's climbing a wall, chewing a corner.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: It's a living thing, Brian. It breathes, it eats, and it hates.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: The only way to beat it is to think like it. To know that this flame will spread this way across the floor not because of the physics of flammable liquids or heat convection, but because it wants to.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: . It darts west. Licks the ceiling. The fire purrs and hisses. Stretches luxuriously and attacks savagely.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian stares at the flame. A goblin reaching out for him... -- Woosh! Rimgale hits it with a fire extinguisher. In an instant the goblin is gone, the genie in the bottle.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: A young woman's entered.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: She looks at him like he's the dumbest human she's met all week.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Some guys on this job, fire owns them. It makes them fight on its level. But the only way to truly kill it is to love it a little, just like Ronald.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: What the hell are you guys doin'?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: We're the fire department, lady.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Well color me stupid, I always thought the fire dept. put out fires.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (to woman) You work here?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Till yesterday. What do you think the odds are that a non-refundable ticket to Paris survived this?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Somewhere between zero and no way.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Shit. What a mess.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You seem real broken up about Mr. Holcomb.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Jeff Holcomb? The Darth Vader of tax accountants? He was a sleezeball. Hopefully a sleezeball that carried some insurance.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Go talk to the building owner.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: He was the building owner.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Our book lists the owner as Dekom Trust.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Don't investigators come in adult size?

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen's lying sprawled on his bunk, his hands pressed over his eyes. There's a voice outside the door.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: A beat, then Rimgale himself enters.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale takes in Stephen's room, the half empty bourbon bottle. Without a word, Rimgale walks over and pours it out. He sits down beside Stephen.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: A wave of pain rolls through Stephen.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen's eyes meet Rimgale's and hold.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen takes Rimgale's notebook out of his lap, rips out a page, and writes angrily in huge block letters.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen throws the sheet at Rimgale, stands, and walks out.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Stevie? Rimgale's here to see you.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I'm busy.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: He just wants to -- STEPHEN -- I'm busy goddamn it, okay?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: What, they don't knock on your planet?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I still haven't gotten your fire report, Stevie. On Tim.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I'm working on it.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I deal with this stuff every day. But a fireman... you never get used to it. (beat) What happened up there? He was a candidate. Did he pay attention? Was he listening?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: ...He wasn't listening to the right thing...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: What do you listen to, Stephen?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You don't know... nobody knows...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I might.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: It knows us. This one knows us.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (beat) I need that report, Lt.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Tim-went-to-the-fire-and-now-he- doesn't-have-a-face.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: An Escher drawing of a place, endlessly vast racks spun around an open central core. High up, lost among its rows, Brian is going through rack after rack of dog-eared record books as Rimgale enters down below.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (trying to hold it together in his mind) Hey boss, Dekom Trust is owned by Pan Illinois... which is majority controlled by Lakeside Dynamics... which is a division of Windy City Ventures... who's partners are... (beat) Alan Seagrave, Donald Cosgrove, and Jeffrey Holcomb.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Son of a bitch. They knew each other.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: More books. Files. Acres of paper.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: A beat, then he looks directly at Brian.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: So Seagrave and Holcomb were accountants...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: And Cosgrove. Coppers figured he laundered money for the mob before getting into real estate. They weren't very high on Seagrave, either.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Nice bunch of guys.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Who all ended up wearing candles for faces... (beat) Swayzak's up to his ass in this somehow. Guy can barely hold a drink in his hand, he's so scared.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: We need to get a look at his files.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: With glowing skyscrapers leaping up in the background, it's an unexpectedly quiet, serene place along the lake. Jennifer sits alone at a bench, watching an ancient fisherman look for dinner, as Brian walks up.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: And it hangs between them, two people lonely on the edge of the lake.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Hi.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Hi.

dialogue.name: dialogue
