dialogue.raw_text: We still talking? (beat) Look, I'm sorry about the other day -- BRIAN Swayzak knows something about the guys that were murdered. I want to know why he keeps that hidden.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I don't know anything about it.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You could check. It'd be in his files.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (beat) Do you know what you're asking me to do?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Yes.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Y'know, four years ago I was working in a bakery. Two years ago I was bringing Marty coffee and he didn't even know my name. I run that office now. Marty believed in me and I believe in him. You want me to just throw that away?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Your boss is lying, Jennifer.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: At a workbench, under a single lamp, Stephen stands amongst a confusion of tools, wire, And a wall socket. With a pair of pliers, he tugs at something within the socket, puts the face-plate back on and screws it down. He stares at it, and we feel the sudden wave of hopelessness cascading through him. He sets the socket back down -- and SCATTERS everything aside in a single, furious move.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen's sits quietly against Helen's back door, lost in himself. A light comes on. Helen opens the back door.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: She sits down beside him.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The moment lingers, grows heavy and grey.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Stephen?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry... I... couldn't sleep...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: What's wrong?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: ... (beat) It used to be, when I was a kid, what meant most to me about this job was there were no ifs. Life and death, right and wrong. When someone called the fire department, we came... Those guys don't know how much I love them... You don't leave people hanging... cause that's what it's all about. It's loyalty. It's 'till death do us part. Isn't that what you heard?... It's you go, we go... Cause without that, it's the end of families, it's the end of the fire department... and when the fire department stops coming... that's the end of the fucking world... (beat) I'm sorry I came, Helen, it's just... it's just there's nobody I can talk to... (beat) I miss you.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen and Helen in bed, holding each other...

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Morning, and Stephen dressed, making eggs for three. Sean's there, lending a hand, beaming as Stephen tries to show him how to flip an egg. Helen enters in her robe. He kisses her.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen musses his son's hair and follows her out into the hall.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The blow's so long and hard and deep you don't even see it.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Just then, Sean sticks his head into it.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Helen's turned away.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Cook and I are almost finished here. Have a seat.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Stephen... I... can I talk to you a second...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Look, I'm sorry I -- HELEN -- No, that's okay. It's just Sean...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: He's gettin' good on those eggs. And y'know, he told me he actually likes the piano.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I don't want to confuse him, Stephen.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: It's... It's just things have changed... you're the same, Stephen, but things are different now... you've got a son... you're the best at what you do Stephen, you always were, but you scare me now...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (to Sean) Hey... Sean-man, your dad blew it. I forgot I had to work this morning...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Aw dad, c'mon...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Next time, huh? We'll do it up big. Promise.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Okay. (then sotto) Mom's crying, dad.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Jennifer enters Swayzak's inner office. His chair's turned away toward the window.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Finally the chair turns, revealing a haunted man. Polls are far from his mind.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: She sees a fire department file on the murders open on his desk.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Swayzak's eyes are dead metal.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: And he turns his chair around again. Jennifer stands there a beat. -- Then turns to the filing cabinets.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (holding print-out) Latest polls came in, Marty. (he doesn't answer) Marty?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Jesus Christ, Marty, what's going on?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Leave me alone.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: We've come a long way together, Marty. I've staked my whole career on you. And now you're sneaking around this office, leaking things to the papers behind my back... (beat) Is there something you're not telling me about these deaths?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: No.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian drives up and parks. He's half way to the staircase when he sees someone sitting in the dark in a car.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: She hands him a manila envelope.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Silence.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: She starts her car.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Jennifer?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: What is -- JENNIFER Just take it.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: That's a dumb thing to say.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You're right.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Goodbye, Brian.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: A cavernous hall full of dozens of fire trucks loaded on jacks. Rimgale's sedan's there, the repairman shaking his head in amazement at the undercarriage.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale's looking through the report Brian's handed him.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: He dumps three more reports on Rimgale.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian hands him something else. A photograph. Swayzak and the other three, posing on a fishing boat, 1970. Time of their lives.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: What the hell do you do with this thing?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: This is the copy of Swayzak's manning report that was released. Everybody on this job knows it's bullshit but we could never argue with the numbers. They're all airtight.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Yeah? Airtight?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I've got three different drafts of the same report -- with different numbers that're all over the place. Looks like they were just making it up as they went along.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Did a little check on the consulting firm that wrote the report. They did exactly one job -- Swayzak's manpower study. It's not even really a company. No employees, no directors, just a PO Box.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Then who wrote the report?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: It had to be someone who knows numbers. Some kind of fancy accountant. But what's the connection?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I think it's time Mr. Swayzak and us had a little heart to heart talk.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The red arson sedan pulls up to wealthy home. Rimgale and Brian walk up and knock on the door -- it creaks open ajar. They push the door open slowly.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: It's dark as they enter.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian and Rimgale split up down different halls. It's the HISS Brian hears first. Then the FLASH of an electrical socket FLARING ice-cold cobalt blue. Suddenly the room's dimensions are there in frantic, strobing shadows. Chairs, a couch -- -- And a figure that JUMPS Brian. the light from the burning plug is a fierce strobe as the figure, a confused shadow, crashes Brian to the floor. They STRUGGLE. The figure GRABS Brian's throat. Brian PUSHES him back

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Hello? Swayzak?

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Against the burning wall plug. The figure SHRIEKS in pain, gets his hand on a crowbar and SLAMS Brian -- who crumples, dazed. The figure stands -- just as Rimgale TACKLES him. The figure CRASHES across a gas space heater, SNAPPING the connection off. The figure SLAMS Rimgale HARD with the crowbar, squirms free, and stumbles out the door. Hissss... Rimgale climbs to his feet as fire eats at the wall. A baby backdraft wagging its tail. He goes to a dazed Brian's side, lifting him by his armpits and

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: helping him outside. Hissss... The ruptured space heater pumps gas furiously. Rimgale sees that. He also sees a bedroom door ajar on the far side of the house. And through the door a couch. And on the couch, A body. Hissss...

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale rushes back inside. It's Swayzak, unconscious.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale drags him out on the stoop beside Brian just as the gas WHUMPS and the doors and windows EXPLODE in a HOWLING FIREBALL, the shrapnel BLOWING Rimgale off his feet. Brian slowly shakes his head clear. He looks around, tries to orient himself.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian climbs up to his feet and walks over to where Rimgale lies at a weird angle, a piece of wrought iron fence punched through his shoulder.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Uh... I sorta got a problem here...

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale lies in an emergency room bed.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale grunts.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale suddenly kicks the bed frame in anger. He kicks it over and over with frustration till something finally SNAPS off. Brian waits, let's him vent his frustration.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Well Brian, I guess you can say it's arson now...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: How ya feeling?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Did you pull me out?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Did I say thanks?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: No.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Just wondering.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I hate hospitals. You're so... so goddamn useless...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: So what do you want me to do?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I've been lying here hours... just thinking... We're close... (beat) We're not looking in the right place, Brian. This one knows us and we're not looking in the right place...

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian's sitting alone in a chair. Finally the opposite door opens and in enters Ronald.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian hands him a stack of murder files.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: As Ronald starts to read the files

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Well, Mr. Life magazine. Come all this way just to say hi?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I'm close... but I can't get who it is...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: So you came to me... (smiles) Well, this is going to be an interesting afternoon after all...

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: LATER - DAY Brian still sitting there. Watching Ronald devour the statistics. The photos of charred bodies. Ronald finishes, leans back.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Ronald drops on the table a dog-eared copy of that 1972 LIFE magazine with Brian on the cover.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: In a flash, Brian suddenly reaches across and grabs Ronald by the collar.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: And Ronald sees something in Brian's eyes. He smiles.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian releases Ronald.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The arsonist smiles a creepy, horrible grin.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: A cold shock rolls through Brian as he slumps back in his chair.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Okay, here's the deal. I'll tell you a story, you tell me one. Fair?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Who's doing this?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Your first question should be who isn't. It isn't a spark, Brian. Not enough damage. And an insurance pro? Where's the profit margin?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Then who -- RONALD -- No no, your turn. Tell me a story.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I don't have a story.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Sure you do.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Famous story even. Straight burn. Just an engine and truck first on scene. What did you feel, Brian, when you first got there?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: What?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You gotta tell a story too, Brian. It's fair. C'mon, don't think too hard -- BRIAN I... I thought it was great. I loved it. It was nothing to these guys... medium deal.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Right. Light smoke, low roll. Couple'a civilians hollering -- medium deal. So young fireman Adcox and Captain McCaffrey, they head up stairs, get out on the fire escape -- McCaffrey does the ballsy jump across... what were you feeling, Brian? (Brian doesn't answer) C'mon, you promised. Be honest. (Brian just stares) Okay... Guard!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I wanted to be him. Right then I wanted to be him more than anything...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (smiles) Very good, Brian. -- About your report here. The way to a torch's heart is through his tools. That's how you know him. It's the way he talks to the fire. And to you if you listen.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: The outlets.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: That's a probie answer. You're smarter than that, Brian.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Trychticholorate.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Good. -- So our two heroes, Adcox and McCaffrey, they go back inside. Only there's another fire in there nobody sees. And it took your dad, didn't it Brian? Did you see him burn?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Who the fuck is doing this?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: After it took your dad... the fire... did it look at you Brian? Did it talk to you?...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You see, our world's aren't so different...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (quiet) Who's doing this?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Think, Brian. Who doesn't love fire, but knows it better than anyone else? Who's around trychticholorate 24 hours a day?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Oh Jesus Christ...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Not such a far walk after all, is it, Brian?

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian climbs up onto Stephen's boat. Nobody home. He opens the cabin door, goes inside and hits the lights.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: There's cereal bowls in the sink, beer bottles on the table, And a stack of fire department supplies in the corner. His whole body aching with reluctance, Brian begins looking through them. Solvents, Armorall, a small specialty can of fire dept. chemicals. There's a label of ingredients on it. Way down at the bottom, Is trychticholorate. Nausea wracks its way through Brian.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Footsteps. Brian spins around in stone shock as Stephen comes into the cabin.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian backs away from the chemicals.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: He KICKS the bulkhead wall.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian turns to leave. Pauses.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian sees the chemicals in the corner again and something freezes up inside. Stephen catches the look and there's horrible silence between them.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Oh goddamn it Stephen...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Hey, what are you doing here?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Just... Just wanted to say hello...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: So hello.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Well, long as you're here you can help clean up a little. I've got a guy coming to look at this in a few minutes.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You're selling dad's boat?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, it's just another memory in my life right now. And I got way too many of them...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I really should get back. There's... there's something I'm supposed to do.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Yeah? What have you got to do? (beat) Look at you. Look at your face. All the things you must be thinking. Man, you must really hate my guts. Well, you know what? It's okay.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Look, Stephen, maybe we can talk about this some other -- STEPHEN -- Okay, so you don't like me. You don't like everything I've done. What, because I wasn't such a genius the way I raised you? Jesus Christ, dad was gone, what was I supposed to do? You tell me, what the fuck was I supposed to do?!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: It's okay, Stephen, I -- STEPHEN -- I tried, y'know? Helen's right. I don't have all the answers, but goddamn it, I've got some. (beat) Look, you're gonna do what you have to, and maybe I shouldn't have gotten in the way. I'm your brother, not your father. Go on. You gotta go somewhere? Go...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I saw it.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Saw what?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: When dad died, I saw another fire...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Everybody did.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I saw it before it got them. I tried to yell, but... He asked me to look out for him. And I didn't do it. I let him die.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (stunned) ...Jesus, you been carrying that around for twenty years? For christ's sake, you were seven years old! You think he could have heard you in there?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I hate him so much sometimes, Stephen. You don't know how hard it was for me to put that uniform on...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Maybe I do. (sighs) ...What a fuckin' mess, huh? (beat) People can change Brian.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Sometimes right when you're looking at them.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Oh God, Stephen, what's going on with you?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I don't know, Brian... I don't know...

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian stands before the fire station. His brother's and his.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian PRIES the lock off Stephen's locker. Starts looking through it. Adcox comes out of the shower with a towel on, starts shaving in a mirror. He doesn't notice Brian. Adcox turns to head for his own locker and the towel slips a little. And Brian's universe caves in. An icy claw tears out his stomach. Gulping breaths, he forces himself to look at Adcox's back. On it is a small, rectangular burn. It's fresh and it's the size of a wall socket. At that moment Adcox turns. The two of them stare at one another just a beat, then Adcox walks past him. Just then the alarm bells RING. Brian hesitates a beat, confused, then turns and runs down to

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Where firemen are scurrying around, suiting up. Brian looks frantically for Stephen, sees him out back.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: (breathless)

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Grindles sticks his head out the back door.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Grindle goes back in.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen turns and walks toward the station. Brian's eyes go to a window just above it. There, watching him, watching the whole exchange between brothers, is Adcox. Adcox stares at Brian a beat, then finally disappears as Brian hears the cough of diesel engines.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: He starts running for the station.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Stephen, wait a minute. I gotta talk to you. It's Adcox, he's -- STEPHEN -- What are you doing here?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I saw Adcox's back! I saw the burn! I put it there! Jesus Christ, Stephen, he's been killing people!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I know.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: How do you know?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I knew when you came looking for the chemicals. Looking for me.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: What were they doing there?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: They were for the fucking boat, Brian.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: We gotta roll, Stevie...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I'll be there.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: They're waitin' man.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I'll be there, goddamn it!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (to Brian) Anything else?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: What are we going to do about this?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I'll handle it.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: We gotta go to Rimgale, Stephen.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I'm his Lt. He's my responsibility. I'll handle it. Me.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Christ. Stephen...

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: It's too late. Adcox climbs aboard just as the engine company pulls out and whistles down the street. The ladder company is just easing onto the drive. Brian hesitates only an instant, then runs to the equipment racks, PULLS off the hooks his helmet, coat, boots -- and jumps onto the truck as it takes off in pursuit.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: As it howls down the avenue, Stephen turns around and stares at Adcox sitting behind. The glimmer of an understanding...

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The laddermen look confused seeing Brian sitting among them.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Suddenly CUTS the truck company off. The driver SLAMS the brakes, PUSHING the truck company into a HORRIBLE SKID. The back fishtails, the wheels JUMP the curb, BASH a mailbox, and then the whole rig ROLLS onto its side and DRAGS to a stop. It's tangled confusion in the rear cab. Firemen, unhurt, piled atop one another. Brian slides his way out from under them and looks down the street where plumes of smoke rise six blocks away. He starts running.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Flames and smoke curl from a huge industrial warehouse along the river as Brian, panting, runs up. He searches frantically through the maze of arriving engine companies, looking for number 17. There it is but nobody's home. Brian stops a passing captain.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian looks up at the smoke and whirling firestorm four stories above him, feels the bile of fear in his throat, the desperation, -- And begins strapping on an air tank.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Where are they? Where's 17?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: On the roof.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian, now fully suited up, climbs the endless rungs of an extended aerial ladder.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Tongues of flame ROCKET skyward through ragged holes. Black clouds drift murderously, roofing tars bubble and hiss as the roof itself GROANS like a comatose dinosaur, reminding you the whole thing could go any minute -- and you with it. Trudging alone across this alien, spongy surface, Brian looks for his company. It's almost impossible to tell anyone apart, faces hidden behind helmets and masks. Suddenly a cloud of smoke clears and there's two firemen near the edge, "17" on their helmets.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The helmets look up. Stephen and Adcox. Facing each other. Adcox cradles an axe.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian starts to move beside Stephen but Adcox turns, tightens his grip on the axe, and now all the cards are on the table. A hissing black cloud drifts through. They're the only three people on earth. Adcox's eyes are clouded with tears.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian and Stephen are backed up against the roof edge -- sixty feet up. Far below a fireboat has begun pumping a massive stream at the side of the building.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: And there's a horrible glimmer of confusion on Stephen's face.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Stephen --

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Brian?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Aw man, Stephen, listen to me...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: What the fuck were you thinking, huh? Burning people? You're a fireman.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: They were killing firemen, man. When Sally showed me what was in Swayzak's files... They were my friends, I had to do it. I had to do it for the department.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Did you do it for Tim?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (pain, to Stephen) That was an accident! Jesus Christ, why did you have to go in there so fucking early? Why didn't you listen to me!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You gotta let me finish -- BRIAN Just come down, John. Just -- AXE -- Shut up! Your dad would fucking puke if he saw how you've shit on his department!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Knock it off!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (to Stephen)

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You can't let him turn you against your friends, man -- BRIAN -- He killed people -- AXE -- You know what Swayzak would do to the department if this got out? -- BRIAN -- Stephen, this is bullshit -- AXE -- What he would do to your dad's department? You gotta let me finish it --

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You're his Lt., Stephen... (beat) Are you gonna handle it? Are you Stephen?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Shut up!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: ...What do you want me to do, Stephen? Talk to me. What am I supposed to do?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (beat) There's a fire. We've got a job here. Let's get on with it.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The rest of the crews are totally oblivious to what's happening through the smoke on the other side. Grindle and Santos feel the roof go suddenly spongy beneath them.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Everybody drops their equipment and runs for the edges as

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Shit... It's going! Clear the roof! Now!

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: . AL - NIGHT Brian, Stephen and Adcox react as the roof HOWLS and GROANS and huge SPLITS begin racing along it. And then it goes. The center section DROPS, and in rolling waves of SCREECHING steel, the hole spreads outward; DEVOURING. Adcox shoves them aside and runs for his life as the hole races for them, SWALLOWING roof.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: And Brian balls-out dashes for the edge. Stephen's made one corner, Brian desperately heads for another. At the last instant -- as the HOWLING FLAME BELLOWS UP to his ankles -- Brian LEAPS OFF the roof -- EXT. WAREHOUSE - FIRE ESCAPE - NIGHT -- And falls half a story before CRASHING onto an exterior fire escape. Flames have cut off the fire escape two floors below, so Brian climbs down as far as possible, crawls onto a ledge, KICKS out a window, steps through, And falls.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Jesus Christ Brian, run! Run goddamn it!

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Blackness and emptiness, two stories of it, before he CRASHES into a pool of water at the bottom. He's in a freight elevator shaft, thrashing madly, drowning. Great SHEETS of WATER are POURING through an upper doorway and CASCADING down like monsoon rain.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: We see it's coming from the fireboat's rushing stream.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The weight of his equipment is pulling Brian underwater. Struggling against the insane swirls and the sheets of water still POURING DOWN, Brian unhooks his air tank. He leans back, tries to float on the rising column of water. -- His coat catches on something -- YANKS him underwater. He struggles feverishly -- finally tears the coat off. The building GROANS in earnest. Flaming chunks of plaster CRASH down around Brian, forcing him to duck underwater. The place is coming apart. Ten feet above, one of the falling chunks SMACKS a gas main, SPLITTING then IGNITING it. A white-hot JET OF FLAME SHOOTS from one side of the shaft to the other. Brian's floating okay, he's floating right up into the flames. Brian tries to flatten himself out, to keep everything but his nose below water, but he's still moving up -- the heat becoming so intense his face flares and he's ducking under water now, trying to stay alive, trying to decide whether to drown or burn -- -- When there's a CRASH. And suddenly another door on the shaft is tearing open. There's a glint of an axe. A flashlight. It's Stephen. Brian has about two seconds left. In that time Stephen sees the shut-off for the gas line mounted on the wall opposite. It's unreachable, a good twelve feet across a horizontal curtain of flame. Before we can even assimilate that, Stephen's already jumped. A crazy leap over the fire. He SMACKS the opposite wall, HITS the shut-off, and FALLS CRASHING into the pool beside Brian.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian helps him stay above water. The level continues to rise, bringing them finally even with an open doorway they scramble through.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You crazy son of a bitch, why couldn't you stay behind a desk where you belong?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: "You never know till the fire stares you down if you're gonna be --" STEPHEN Oh shut up, huh? (grimaces) I think I broke my goddamn arm...

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: It leads to a stairwell that's become a RAGING TORRENT of water spilling down it. No way. They push through to the next doorway and out onto

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The place is full of hundreds of chemical drums. The fire has cracked its way into the room as WUMP -- drums begin EXPLODING, SHOOTING UPWARD Roman candle fountains of glittering FLAME. Brian helps Stephen as they snake their way past sweating drums -- pressure valves hissing madly with desperation. They duck low, round a corner,

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: And walk right into an axe handle that SMACKS Brian's throat KNOCKING him gasping flat on his back. It's Adcox. Stephen JUMPS Adcox and TACKLES him on the edge of a metal platform that extends out from the raised flooring.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Adcox struggles against him, heaving and sobbing.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: And Adcox releases the axe.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian's on his feet now, coming toward them, when a chemical drum below EXPLODES, the shock wave BUCKLING the platform and DROPPING it several feet before it HOLDS. Brian, cut- off, is HIT with a wall of debris. Adcox and Stephen are FLUNG across the platform and THROUGH the shattered railing. Stephen grabs a piece of broken, dangling strut and hangs on with one hand. In his other hand is Adcox. Hanging below him, his grip loosening.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian's struggling to get out from under the debris. The railing Stephen's hanging onto is slick, his hand SLIPPING along it. But he won't let go of Adcox. His eyes bore into his best friend's with absolute conviction.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The towering shots of FLAME from below have begun to IGNITE Adcox's pant leg. He's starting to burn. But Stephen won't let go. Won't let go even as the flames crawl up Adcox's back. And Stephen's hand is slipping and slipping and then it isn't slipping anymore because it's come off.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Adcox and Stephen FALL. There's a narrow catwalk half-way down. Stephen HITS with a sickening CRUNCH. Adcox falls past it, down into the flames. There's an exposed I-beam running from the ruined platform out over the catwalk. Brian climbs up onto it, balances across over the fire below and jumps down to the catwalk where his brother lies, battered but still alive.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You stupid son of a bitch! What the fuck are you doing!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Stevie... I...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Let it go! Goddamn it let it go!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry... I'm so sorry...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Stephen!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You go, we go.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You're gonna be all right, man.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian looks down and across the factory floor. There, coming through the doorway, is Pengelly and Nightengale with a hoseline.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Hey! Over here! They start for him when another drum EXPLODES, FLATTENING them and launching their hoseline into a crazy, thrashing arc. The flame has cut them off from the hose. Stephen sees what Brian's thinking.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: But Brian's already moving for the catwalk ladder.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian puts his feet on the outside rungs of the ladder and SLIDES down to the factory floor. He's heading for the hoseline when WHAM! -- The fire cuts him off. Not just any fire. That same one from so many years ago. Don't fuck with me, kid. I'm not in the mood. Nightengale's lost his helmet and it's lying near the flames spinning slowly upside down -- just like his father's. Brian stands there, paralyzed, as the fire laughs at him. Same old little kid with his finger up his ass. Then something different comes into Brian's eyes.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: There's a pathetic little wall extinguisher mounted on the pole. Brian lifts it, approaches the fire. You can practically hear the flames laugh at him. Brian suddenly turns and SLAMS the neck of the extinguisher against the pole, BREAKING it off before HEAVING the cannister HISSING into the flames where it EXPLODES -- a cloud of extinguisher powder that STUNS the flames just long enough for Brian to dash through and TACKLE the hose. The fire shakes off the powder, rises up to kill -- Just as Brian spins and HITS it with the STREAM.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Wait for another hose team...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Wait for the goddamn hose team!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: No... No more.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: And it's like a howling train wreck as the two grapple with each other -- Pengelly and Nightengale have an opening, and they're dashing for the catwalk ladder up to Stephen because the fire doesn't care -- it only has eyes for Brian now -- -- And Stephen sees Brian tackle the monster, and his eyes fill with tears -- -- And the fire's pushing Brian -- pushing him with the fury of a frightened street bully -- but Brian won't give -- and now the fire's back's broken -- it's whimpering, dying. And Pengelly and Nightengale have climbed up to Stephen now, pulling him away.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: And the fire's just a little gremlin now, sighing sadly as Brian steps up with the hoseline.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: And whoosh, it's gone.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: That's my brother! That's my brother goddamn it!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Another time, friend.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian rushes up as paramedics load his brother into an ambulance.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: As Brian jumps in with him

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (smiles, weak) You are such a pain in the ass...

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Paramedics swarm over Stephen as the ambulance screams through the night. Brian's right there, holding his hand.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: His brother squeezes Brian's hand, his eyes never leaving him.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Stephen's EKG's begun to falter. The other paramedic fires off an injection into his IV.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The EKG's become erratic. Stephen's eyes never leave Brian's.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: They put an ambo bag over Stephen's face. The eyes never leave Brian's.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: They're breathing for him now. The EKG begins shrieking.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The paramedics begin scrambling to load the defibrillator pads on Stephen's chest. But the fireman's eyes never waver from Brian. They look into his with complete conviction, complete acceptance, And then they don't.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Don't tell them about Adcox... Don't let 'em...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry... I'm sorry I thought... I won't.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (reading EKG) Oh shit, give him some lidocaine, now. Now.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (beat) Who's your brother?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: His pressure's fading -- push some adrenalin.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Oh man, don't you die... Don't you die...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: #2 He's going south... He's gonna box damn it...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Goddamn it don't you die now... Not now!

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: V-fib!

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: : Then, FADE UP TO:

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: A silent, quiet street absolutely empty of traffic. Then over the crest of Chicago's mightiest thoroughfare, creeps slowly a fire engine. It's emergency lights are on but not the siren. This engine isn't in a hurry today. Behind comes another fire engine. And another. Ten, twenty, all of them creeping slowly along. And behind the engines now walk firemen in their dress blues. Hundreds of them. Walking silently in step behind

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Loaded in the rear of Engine 17. Santos drives as Grindle, Brian, and the men of ladder company 46, walk behind. The silent procession passes under extended aerial ladders crossed like dress swords. Average people stop, take their hats off.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Two coffins, lying side by side, draped in the blue and white of the Chicago flag. A single fire helmet rests atop each casket. Brian stands at attention beside Helen. He holds the hand of Stephen's son Sean, his eyes clouded with tears as a fire dept. honor guard plays Taps. Jennifer's there, too far away to touch. Rimgale, still wearing a head bandage, stands stiffly beside a brass bell and speaks with a voice raw and weary.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: With a small hammer Rimgale rings out 3-3-5 on the bell. The honor guard folds the flag covering Stephen's casket and hands it to Helen, who holds it to her breast as we

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: In the Chicago Fire Department the alarm code 3-3-5 signifies that the company has returned home to quarters. We will now ring out that code to welcome home John Adcox and Stephen McCaffrey...

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: A sea of blue uniforms drifting across green as the funeral breaks up. Brian hugs Helen and Sean. Lets them go.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale's there, resting against his dept. sedan as Brian walks by, pauses, and leans on it beside him. A beat.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale turns to walk back to his sedan. He pauses. Looks back to Brian.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Your brother was a good man.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Another couple of good men get burned up for their city? Is that how it's going to read? (Brian doesn't answer) You're the only one that knows.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Like it never happened...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Want to help me with something?

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: An elevator opens as Brian and Rimgale walk quickly out, down a hall, and BURST into Swayzak's office.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The Alderman's there, giving a press conference from his desk.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale sits on Swayzak's desk.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Rimgale drops the manning report on Swayzak's desk.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: The room explodes with questions. Through the din Brian leans over the desk very close to Swayzak.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian turns and pushes his way out. At the door he pauses and looks back at Rimgale. The investigator nods and smiles just a little...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Swayzak! How ya doin'?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (confused) Investigator...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I'm a little busy right now -- SHADOW This'll only take a minute. There's two cops outside that want to ask you about this --

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: This is just a guess of course, but I think they're gonna want to know why you secretly paid Donald Cosgrove, Jeffrey Holcomb and Alan Seagrave to create a phony manpower study. (to cameras) You guys'll wait, right?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: See that glow flashing in the corner of your eye? That's your career dissipation light. And it just went into high gear.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: As Brian walks down it, Rimgale appears and calls to him.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian hesitates.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: And there's just a beat between the investigator and his probie before Brian nods and walks away.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Brian.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: Don't keep looking over your shoulder for the ghost. It's gone now.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian walks down the hall. He passes Jennifer's small office. She's in there, surrounded by packing boxes.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I think your boss is going to need some spin control.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I quit two days ago, Brian.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: (beat) What'll you do?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I don't have the slightest idea...

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: I'll see ya around, huh?

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: It's a small town.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: And morning breaking across the avenues and up against the tired brick of firehouse 17.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: Brian sits staring into his locker, lost in thought, his equipment stacked up on the bench beside him. THE ALARM KLAXON SOUNDS INT. FIRE STATION 17 - APPARATUS FLOOR And firemen scurrying to their equipment on the apparatus floor. They're climbing aboard their rigs now and the pumper's diesel is coughing to life. At the last moment, as it begins to pull out, Brian comes sliding down the pole in his turn-out gear, bounces off the floor, and climbs aboard as the engine WHISTLES away.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: There's a new fireman beside him on the bench. He can't get his coat buckled right. Brian leans over does it for him.

dialogue.name: dialogue
dialogue.raw_text: You're doing it wrong.

direction.name: direction
direction.raw_text: And the fire engine slips away from us, down the avenue, into the city as we
